title: Never Let Me Go
author: Ishiguro, Kazuo*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Along with writing s here at goodreads, for the past few years I've had a channel on YouTube featuring videos of myself discussing the books I'vAlong with writing s here at goodreads, for the past few years I've had a channel on YouTube featuring videos of myself discussing the books I've read. I rely on what what's been written here for much of the content I deliver there. If you want to know what I thought about a book, come to goodreads to read it. If you'd prefer to listen, go to Roy's Book Reviews on YT. Since I now compose s keeping in mind that I'll later be referring to them for my video recordings, I write in greater detail and higher word count these days than used to be the case. My gr s serve as scripts for the videos to follow. Writing about Kazuo Ishiguro's heart breaking novel Never Let Me Go substantially enough to make a video later is a challenge I may not be up to. This isn't because I cannot think of plenty to say about it. But the thing is, I don't want either my written or video  to serve as spoiler. This is not a novel with a surprise, twist ending. Rather, it's a story that reveals secrecy in incremental degrees. Little by little we find out what the protagonist knows and does not yet know about her circumstances and destiny. Incidents that do not seem particularly monumental to us are revealed as she reflects on her memories, with their importance not to be understood by the reader until later on. By the time we've figured out what's going on, we are invested in the lives of the central characters. Once invested, it's human nature to root for some version of a happy ending. Our best wishes are the result of our humanity. I suppose that the nature of humanity is what the beautiful novel Never Let Me Go is ultimately about. Above all else, what we tend to never let go of until it's pulled from our grasp is hope. Without hope, what are we and why are we here?...more

title: Black Cake
author: Wilkerson, Charmaine
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Black Cake by Charmaine Wilkerson is an enjoyable read that is easy to turn through the pages of. It features an ambitious narrative that jumps back aBlack Cake by Charmaine Wilkerson is an enjoyable read that is easy to turn through the pages of. It features an ambitious narrative that jumps back and forth in time and is told from multiple points of view. It's a decent sized book that is broken up into many short chapters, hopping from character to character, past to present. It's a story about secrets, and I don't want to give too many of them away because I am anti-spoiler, not that I found most of the them to be especially earth shattering. In the present time, estranged siblings are brought together upon the death of their mother. A few years earlier when their father passed away, it failed to result in a reunion because the sister did not show up. Or rather, she chose not to make her presence known. She is less professionally accomplished than her brother, who is a notable oceanographer with an appreciative fan base. He is the sensible one who seems to know what he wants out of life and typically does what's required to accomplish it. His sister on the other hand can't make up her mind about what to study in school, what to do for a living, whether she is straight or lesbian. She does not blow off her mother's funeral like her dad's, and once back in her childhood home she listens to a tape left behind for her and her brother. In the recording that a lawyer plays for them (mild secret revelation, he was also her boo), their mother reveals a lifetime of family secrets. We readers learn along with Byron and Benny that their mother was not quite who they thought she was. Same applies to their father. Also learned (one more secret I'm giving away in this , but trust me, there is no shortage of them) is that they have a half sibling. I enjoyed that the setting of Eleanor Bennett's youth was a Caribbean island since I happen to be from one myself (St. Thomas, USVI). As someone who grew up in a West Indian household, I've had my fair share (though it's been a little while since my last taste) of black cake - aka rum cake. I think that Charmaine Wilkerson did a solid job of managing so many different storylines and characters in a manner that was not confusing. I wanted to love this novel more than I ended up doing. It somehow felt overly drawn out and yet rushed at the same time. Plenty was revealed, and I'm not saying that I predicted much of it, but I simply didn't find many of the revelations to be especially startling. I just kept on reading until getting to the next one. In the end, regardless of all the mystery and secrecy, Black Cake is a story of family - and our obligation to forgive those who comprise it as much as we can since we only get one. Or so we think. Sometimes it's a bit more complicated than that. There is a TV series adaptation of Black Cake on Hulu. Perhaps I will check it out, if only to see how faithful it is to the source material and to watch a program that no doubt will be filled with a bunch of very attractive Black people. Overall I do recommend this novel, even if only for its strong start that sucks you in immediately but significantly loosened in grip on my attention as the story drew to a close. I suggest pairing Black Cake with a dish of jerk chicken or curry goat from the nearest Jamaican spot. They can't all be 5-star reads, but you may appreciate this book more than I did, and there is only one way to find out for sure....more

title: House of Leaves
author: Danielewski, Mark Z.*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: House of Leaves by Mark Z. Danielewski is by far the strangest book I have ever read. It gets a 5 out of 5 stars rating on sheer audacity alone, whichHouse of Leaves by Mark Z. Danielewski is by far the strangest book I have ever read. It gets a 5 out of 5 stars rating on sheer audacity alone, which isn't to say that it doesn't also earn high marks because the readable parts are beautifully written. Describing a book as having "readable parts" infers that other parts are - something different. Experimental is a genre of fiction, and this may be the only experimental novel I've read, yet I still feel confident that it's probably the best one ever written. There are plenty of different ways to feel upon completion of a great literary work. You may want to go back to page 1 and read it all over again. You may go looking for any and everything else that author has written. You may start an online campaign demanding a sequel. Some will go looking for books on similar topics or that touch upon similar themes. Or perhaps you will choose a very different type of book for your next read to prevent it from suffering in comparison to the masterpiece you just devoured. The thought that occurred to me upon reading House of Leaves is that I would love to meet the author and hang out with him for a bit. Anyone who could think up and then execute such a Frankenstein's monster of a book must surely be a fascinating conversationalist - no matter the topic. Either that or else I wouldn't be able to keep up with his stream of consciousness. House of Leaves features a layering of narrative points of view built upon other narrative points of view, and the reader is repeatedly snatched from one to another with no apparent pattern, rhyme or reason. I'll describe it as best I can but I'm not holding myself accountable for making sense. Why should I do that as er when being comprehensible was of so little concern to the author of the book I'm ing? Most authors strive for readability. Their intent is entertain, doing so by making you feel and think and connect with their characters. Maybe even like at least one of them. Then there's this book. Danielewski's goal with House of Leaves almost seems to be daring us to continue. The reader is never comfortable. House of Leaves is I suppose the exact opposite of a cozy mystery. It sure is mysterious, but it's impossible to feel cozy when getting yanked all over the place. For example, numerous times I found myself having to decide whether to continue reading the page I was on or jumping ahead for continuity and then jumping back to follow a different thread. No matter what I did, there was no right or wrong answer. It's my first time ever using a bookmark to remember where to backtrack to. Are you a fan of fiction with footnotes? I thought that I was. The Brief Wondrous Life of Oscar Wao by Junot Diaz is a book that I felt used them beautifully to provide cultural backstory. In House of Leaves, footnotes comprise a whole other book within the one that you're reading. Except the book actually starts out with what later becomes footnotes, so maybe that's the main book and what lays above is the embedded story. Decide for yourself which one is the core story. The text layout is as fascinating as the stories being told in House of Leaves. Depending on where you're at, you may have to go to a corner of the page to find the text. Or turn the book sideways. Or upside down. Or break a code to learn what's being said by using just the first letter of each word. At one point, perhaps my favorite, I had to use my cell phone camera in selfie mode to flip the text around so I could read it. My least favorite section may have been the one with a bunch of letters X'd out, simulating content being lost to fire, so I had to fill out blanks in my mind to recognize what words were written. There are pages that are dense with text and pages that have just a word on two on them. There are numerous passages in French or Latin, some of it translated, some not. Look it up yourself if you want, which would mean leaving the book entirely and then returning. I was not that patient. Many pages I skipped altogether since at a glance I could tell they were not necessary in the building of plots. They were just content that Mark Z. Danielewski took the time to research and present, or else make up and present. I haven't even gotten into giving a storyline synopsis yet, since far more noteworthy than what House of Leaves is about is how it is presented. At one point fairly early on, I noted on Twitter that this book was either going to end up as a Did Not Finish or a 5 star . I saw no way to a middle ground. Wherever/whenever you stop reading (I made it to end of the Appendix which is followed by a lengthy Index), nobody's reaction is going to be "Meh". I understand someone absolutely hating this book as much as I understand someone feeling that it is the greatest thing ever written. In between has no place here. Okay, let me try to summarize now. In House of Leaves there is a man named Will Navidson who is married to a woman named Karen and they have two young kids - a son and a daughter. Navidson is a Pulitzer Prize winning photojournalist, expert at wielding a still camera as well as a video camera. They own a house in Virginia, and one day Navidson notices something odd about its dimensions. The interior is a smidgen wider than the exterior. Like Alice in Wonderland, it isn't long before he finds himself going down the rabbit hole. But it's a very different sort of rabbit hole than the one Lewis Carroll gifted us with. No quirky characters are found within, no childlike wonder. Navidson enters a dark space that wasn't there before but now there it is. He brings others along on his expedition. What does he find? Darkness. Absence of light but impossible continuation of space. Down hallways, through doorways, and then down a very long spiral staircase that eventually leads to...more of the same. Is it Infinity? Is it Hell? Is there a difference? Navidson makes a film about his multiple explorations within the impossible inner dimensions of the house. A man named Zampano studies the film and everything about what happened and apparently goes insane in the process. Another man reads what Zampano left behind and loses his mind and will to resume regular life as well. We, the readers of House of Leaves, read about what Johnny Truant experiences by reading what Zampano learned by studying up on Navidson. Does that make us go crazy? Yeah, probably a little bit. Perhaps not as crazy as Johnny's mother who went insane and tried to kill him as a child. The letters she wrote to him from a mental institution showing her deteriorating state of mine bring House of Leaves to a close. Why? Why not? Best as I can tell, Danielewski wanted to write a novel about the experience of going insane, and the only way for us authentically understand is by being driven insane ourselves. Was Danielewski successful in his quest? Abso-friggin-lutely. Do I recommend his book to others? Yep, but only those bold in literary taste need apply. There are all kinds of things that trigger warnings are given for to let someone know what they're about to venture into - if they dare. Maybe it's sexual content, maybe violence, maybe incest or pedophilia or some other horror. With House of Leaves, the trigger warning for anyone who finds my  is go in knowing that reading this book can drive you nuts. Now you know, so it's up to you whether you care to take that trip. Bravo, Mr. Danielewski. Bravo!...more

title: Persepolis: The Story of a Childhood        (Persepolis, #1)
author: Satrapi, Marjane
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I was not ready for this book. It was a summer reading school assignment for my daughter that I decided to read after she was done with it. She's not I was not ready for this book. It was a summer reading school assignment for my daughter that I decided to read after she was done with it. She's not a big reader, so she lucked out because Persepolis is a graphic novel, meaning that it's a quick read. Turns out that she also lucked out in being assigned a terrific book. I am not the target audience for graphic novels since as much as I love illustrations, words are my jam. This does not mean I'm a fast reader, for the opposite is true. I usually choose to take my time and savor a narrative. Certain page turning thrillers that I can't help but race through are the exception rather than the rule. Persepolis is the second graphic novel I have read to date, the first being Incognegro by Mat Johnson. I really enjoyed that one which also goes into rather intense territory, and I was flat out blown away by Marjane Satrapi's Persepolis: The Story of a Childhood. The title and subtitle tell you what it's about, but that doesn't mean I was prepared for the upbringing detailed in this memoir. As with graphic novels, I don't read a lot of memoirs either. Each of the ones I've read have been excellent and fascinating. I don't see the point in writing a memoir if you have not led a super interesting life. I've enjoyed my own autobiography to date, but I wouldn't bore readers by putting it down on paper. Instead I will steer them to books such as Running with Scissors by Augusten Burroughs, Me Talk Pretty One Day by David Sedaris, and now Persepolis is added to the list. Its author was born and raised in Iran, which is an exceptionally eventful and combustible place to grow up, and to do so as a girl has its own unique set of complications and barriers. Satrapi writes from first person perspective as a child rather than an adult recounting her younger days. That puts the reader in the here and now, which for this story I thought was more effective than us looking back with her on days gone by. It makes the typical reader older and presumably wiser in ways of the world than the protagonist. There is charming naivete to her outlook and interpretation of events, because she is only in her early teens. Yet what she goes through and survives in fourteen years or so is far more than someone who finds their way to this gem of a book in a place far less unstable and volatile than Iran. The narrator reveals impactful events to us in matter of fact fashion, such as one day being a student in a co-ed, non-religious bilingual school - the next day a student in an all girls schools with the wearing of veils now obligatory. No need to embellish drama when so much of it takes place. The contrast between the stylistically simple black and white illustrations and the brutal inhumanity of what is taking place is startling - like a pre-school children's book and a Rated R horror flick merged into one. The amount of devastating events that transpire throughout the course of about 150 pages is staggering. Loved ones are introduced on one page, killed a page or two afterwards. The tragedy just keeps coming. Yet we also can't help smiling in certain places as this stubborn, resilient girl puts together a punk rock look, or goes shopping for music by acts we old enough readers remember from the 1980's, scoring posters of Iron Maiden and Kim Wilde that her parents sneak into the country for her as contraband, or when she takes a forbidden puff of a cigarette in the basement and declares herself to have reached adulthood. Regime changes are detailed at a dizzying pace. No matter who is in charge of things during any given period, repression in one form or another is present, as is danger. Permanence is a foreign concept to this Middle Eastern world. Her immediate family is the only constancy, but how long can it last when the only reliable guarantees are sudden change and arbitrary violence? Since we are reading her book, we know that Marjane Satrapi made it out alive. Writing this book probably helped her to emerge emotionally intact. I read Persepolis over the course of a day but suspect that I'll be thinking about it for a long time....more

title: Killers of the Flower Moon: The Osage Murders and the Birth of the FBI
author: Grann, David*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Killers of the Flower Moon: The Osage Murders and the Birth of the FBI is the true story of horrific one-by-one genocide of Native Americans in the USKillers of the Flower Moon: The Osage Murders and the Birth of the FBI is the true story of horrific one-by-one genocide of Native Americans in the USA. This book came to my attention due to the onslaught of attention being given to a movie adaptation coming out in 2023. It is directed by the legendary Martin Scorcese and features Hollywood heavyweights such as Leonard DiCaprio and Robert De Niro to name just a couple of them. So advance notification that the movie is a superb must-see event was unsurprising. Rather than waiting for the film to drop, since the subject matter piqued my interest in a big way, I decided to first read the book by David Grann that it's based on. Killers of the Flower Moon describes a period which came to be known as the 'Reign of Terror' during which countless members of a Native American tribe named Osage came to be murdered. The word "countless" is used literally here because so much covering up took place, so little follow up in pursuit of justice occurred, and so much sweeping lives under the rug that were deemed to be inconsequential happened, that it's impossible to know with full certainty how many people were murdered - who the killers in each instance were - and who else was involved to make certain that killings went unresolved. What led to the murder spree was that the Osage were involuntarily relocated to an area of Oklahoma by American Whites who were greedily gobbling up the country until they owned it in its entirety. Turns out that they pushed the Osage on to land with plenty of oil later discovered beneath its soil. So instead of gentrifying the Osage into a ghetto, the Osage were made wealthy. This turn of events being unacceptable to greedy American whites with insufficient moral compass to curb their willingness to kill for money, and because the American government refused to acknowledge the Osage as citizens who deserved the same rights as everyone else, or to at least view them as fellow human beings who deserved to be treated with humanity, a system was set up in which ownership of oil rich land could easily be transferred from Osage to White hands. Only deaths were required to make this happen, and willingness to kill Osage people was not in short supply. Much of the narrative centers on a particular villain responsible for multiple murders - a man named William Hale. He could only get what he wanted with agreement and participation from another White man, Ernest Burkhart, who had married an Osage woman named Mollie. The FBI was a brand new organization at the time looking to establish a foothold towards permanence as an American institution - headed by J. Edgar Hoover. The man with boots to the ground who investigated the string of murders in Osage country was Tom White. White did not fully fit the profile that Hoover was looking for in an FBI agent. However, this particular case did not require a suit and tie office type, but a frontier Cowboy. Securing criminal convictions, even with abundance of evidence on hand, was no easy feat when operating in a justice system built to protect certain privileged people and view others as disposable. But Ernest Burkhart eventually developed enough of a conscience to confess his crimes, and this enabled successful conviction of William Hale was well. I believe this is the portion of the story that the movie adaptation focuses on. That's understandable because it features clear cut lead characters, heroes as well as villains, to focus on. But David Grann's book does not stop there. He continues to investigate and comes to learn that the Reign of Terror took place over a longer span of time than had been thought, and involved considerably more people than William Hale and those in his orbit. There were many more victims, more killers, more enablers, more conspiracy to defraud, more covering up awful deeds so well that justice could never be served and descendants can never receive full closure. Here in 2023 we live in this strange time when censorship and book banning are having a revival due to the efforts of intolerant people on the political right. That's one name for them anyway. Bigots is another. They are against books which focus on marginalized people and point a finger of accusation at those who oppress, which of course is simply continuation of the oppression by method of suppression. If kids don't grow up learning about the horrors of slavery and Jim Crow and homophobia and various other institutionalized forms of intolerance, then the American past is white washed and everything is hunky dory. Or so they seem to believe. To quote one of my favorite memes taken from a TV commercial - "That's not how this works. That's not how any of this works". Yet people keep trying and they have made significant headway in the dumbing down of a nation. With this as backdrop, somehow a story like Killers of the Flower Moon manages to find the spotlight. If you are among those who feel that Columbus Day should be eliminated and replaced outright with Indigenous Peoples Day, wait until the exhaustive research of David Grann comes to your attention. If you thought that the worst White Americans did to Native Americans (after all that initial slaughtering) was confining them to tiny sections of this country to still call their own (and perhaps have a casino on), wait until you find out that the slaughter continued on a less grand scale for many more years. First the land is taken, then what lies beneath. Along with the riches generated by the black gold we call oil, what also lies beneath is stated in the book's final paragraph, words spoken by the descendant of a likely victim whose killer was never brought to justice. Mary Jo Webb says: "This land is saturated with blood." Then she repeated what God told Cain after he killed Abel. "The blood cries out from the ground." I look forward to watching the movie version, even though I suspect that it will tell only a part of the story. Perhaps it will make awful people seem more redeemable than they were. Maybe too much focus will be placed on bad people who perpetrated horrors at the expense at honoring the innocent who were steamrolled. But even if imperfectly told to conform to Hollywood's parameters, what's more important is that greater exposure of hidden atrocities will result. Some people, like myself, will dig deeper than just watching a star studded movie and read the book. Others will dig deeper still, find additional books and research, learn more and more about the evil that men did and continue to do in the process of building this extremely flawed, hypocrisy rich nation. You know what they say about those who do not learn / ignore / reject the truth of history. They doom us all. There's nothing exclusively American History about taking lives to claim land, of course. Just turn on the news to see what's going on in Ukraine or Israel and thereabouts. As a reading experience, I found myself a little less absorbed in the narrative of Killers of the Flower Moon despite its high body count and other fascinating elements than I have been with other true crime books. That is because Grann keeps a certain distance from the proceedings. He makes minimal effort to mimic the qualities of an engrossing novel, probably because of the broadness of scope. The fewer people and locations involved, the more intimately a story can be told. Dozens of principle players means less of a microscopic lens on anyone in particular. So I was somewhat less invested than was the case when I've read books such as Truman Capote's In Cold Blood, or Erik Larson's The Devil in the White City. But that doesn't prevent me from giving Killers of the Flower Moon an enthusiastic recommendation....more

title: Crook Manifesto        (Ray Carney, #2)
author: Whitehead, Colson*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: In my  for the last Colson Whitehead book that I read, Harlem Shuffle, I stated that I didn't know what he would cook up for us next but I plannIn my  for the last Colson Whitehead book that I read, Harlem Shuffle, I stated that I didn't know what he would cook up for us next but I planned to be there for it. At the time I did not realize that Harlem Shuffle was not intended to be a standalone title, but part 1 in a series of 3. It had a beginning - middle - end story arc that resulted in a satisfying reading experience given to us from a master at the top of his craft. I have read several Colson Whitehead books. The ones I've enjoyed least are compelling and wonderfully written, and the ones I enjoyed most are among my favorite novels. The man has a gift, and if you haven't read his work and choose not to take my word for it, then perhaps the two Pulitzer Prizes he's won will convince you. In general I am a reader of standalone novels rather than books in a series, with exceptions made to this rule as inspiration strikes. I read multiple Harry Potter titles, for example, although that was largely for my daughter's sake, as they were read aloud to her. I read each of the three books in the Girl with the Dragon Tattoo series, or Millennium series, or whatever you want to call those books by Stieg Larsson, because I was compelled to follow the story all the way through to its end.. Currently I am two thirds of the way through Whitehead's Harlem trilogy, not realizing that I had embarked on a series reading adventure until the second book came out. I enjoyed installment #2- Crook Manifesto. However, I would not say I am quite as fond of it as I was of the novel it is a sequel to. I won't be surprised if I end up loving the third book in the series, whenever it comes out and whatever title it gets, most of all. It will have the advantage of being able to provide a grand finale. Or perhaps Harlem Shuffle, which read to me like a story told in full, will retain its spot as my favorite. The middle title in a 3-book series bears the responsibility of being the bridge between the well drawn set up and the dramatic conclusion. A middle title is informed (and to a degree restrained) both by what came before it and what is planned to come after. If you are reader like me who appreciates when a story he has spent weeks reading feels completed as the final page is reached, then something will inevitably feel a little off about a story that wraps up with a "to be continued" vibe. That said, Crook Manifesto draws us deeper into the world of a man named Ray Carney who is half upstanding, business owning citizen of Harlem, USA in the not especially distant past - and half steeped in the criminal element. When we first meet him in Harlem Shuffle, he is working industriously at maintaining balance between the two opposing aspects of his existence. The straight life has a stronger pull on him because it is reputable and safer, the latter being crucial as he is a family man with a wife and children to consider. But crooked life pays a whole lot better and the more Ray makes from illegal activity like fencing stolen jewels, the more he can afford to invest in his furniture store business and other straight ventures. At the start of Crook Manifesto, Ray believes that he has left the criminal lifestyle inherited from his father behind. The crooked and straight are no longer an even split vying for his divided attention. He is a full blown pillar of the community. This phase comes to a rough end when he needs a favor, to acquire a pair of tickets to a Jackson 5 concert. There is no honest way that he knows of to come by tickets to the sold out event that his daughter is desperate to attend. Ray's intent is to merely dip a toe back into the crooked world, but that world tends to grab hold of whatever little bit is put in and absorbs a person fully. The only way back out is doing whatever illicit activity needs to be accomplished until the newest batch of acquired enemies have been either satisfied or vanquished. Along the way we see that some bad guys masquerade as cops, others as politicians and businessmen. Only the most honest among them pretend to be nothing other than themselves. Rather than staying with Ray for the entire narrative, Crook Manifesto timeshares between Ray and Pepper. The latter is fully invested in criminal life, thoroughly dedicated to resolving matters through violent means when often necessary, a guy who is useful to have on your side and deadly to be up against. Think of Easy Rawlins' sidekick Mouse in Walter Mosley books like Devil in a Blue Dress as a comp. I enjoyed the portions of Crook Manifesto that focused on Pepper's exploits while leaving Ray behind for a while, but it made the story feel a little disjointed. A book that's about Ray becomes one that's about Pepper until it decides to be about Ray again. Nevertheless, a somewhat disjointed bridge book in a series still makes for a better read than a great many other novels - if such a tale happens to be written by someone as talented as Colson Whitehead. I look forward to the third installment in this series, and to my next book which for sure will be a standalone title, and to whatever Colson Whitehead gifts us with once he's done telling his 3-volume Harlem tale....more

review: Timeline is a novel about time travel, and for me it was a time travel reading experience. By that I mean that once upon a time, that time being the 1Timeline is a novel about time travel, and for me it was a time travel reading experience. By that I mean that once upon a time, that time being the 1980's and 90's, Michael Crichton was one of my go-to authors. As I reflect back on my earliest adult novel reading days, I recognize that I tended to be drawn to big shot Best Seller authors. Throughout high school and then college where I majored in English at NYU, the books I read for scholastic purposes were classics from the literary canon. Mostly dead white men. For my leisure reading, I gravitated to household name hotshots of the publishing industry. These authors presumably made out quite well for themselves since we're talking about an era prior to cable television, incredibly realistic video games, and the internet. A period when books were pretty high up on the entertainment hierarchy, and prolific authors of the most popular ones were selling a great many copies. E-books hadn't been invented yet, audiobooks to my knowledge were not super popular yet, so print was king and reading ink on paper was a leisure activity with far less competition than is currently the case. As with the classics from English classes though, I still tended to end up reading novels by white men. But they were still alive and cranking out new titles seemingly as quick as I could read them. In my regular rotation were the books of Sidney Sheldon (who was a favorite author of both my mother and myself), Robin Cook, Stephen King, Joseph Wambaugh, Harold Robbins and Michael Crichton - all writers of popular fiction. I took a pass on Danielle Steele and Jackie Collins, thinking that their books would not contain enough testosterone for my taste. As I grew older I started pulling away from blockbusters comprising the majority of my reads and gravitated more towards literary fiction. This isn't to say that I read only literary fiction these days, or only non-genre books. Life is too short to confine one's self to a single section of the bookstore or library, so I read a little bit of many types of literature. Some books will be literary fiction, some will fall neatly into a genre, some will end up atop Best Seller lists, some will be books that failed to make their authors rich and famous. Of course these days if your name isn't JK Rowling or James Patterson or a small handful of other extremely privileged authors, chances are that you aren't splitting time between multiple mansions, but merely living a comfortable existence when not putting yourself through the hell of the writing process. Reading has not quite become a lost art, but when the phone in your hand is capable of providing such a wide variety of amusements, the book has its work cut out for it to grab short attention spans. Of the authors I used to return to book after book back in the day, Stephen King is one I have read relatively recently. Another author from back then who stood the test of time is John Irving. But the others remained in my rear view mirror. The Michael Crichton books that I enjoyed when wearing a younger man's clothes were Jurassic Park, Congo, and Rising Son. And there were more Crichton stories that I skipped reading and went straight to the movie. Timeline is one of his books that unsurprisingly was made into a film. The man had the Midas touch when it came to addictive storytelling. Unfortunately, I cannot say that I particularly enjoyed Timeline. It's about a small group of historians who end up being able to study the past in an unexpected way when they are sent back into it. I won't bother trying to describe the pseudoscience that a fictional tech company has secretly developed, except to say that it involves the multiverse in a way much less weird than Everything, Everywhere, All at Once - plus the once miraculous seeming and now rather quaint activity of yesteryear called faxing. The characters in Timeline are too unmemorable to bother naming or describing. Suffice it to say that they go back to the 1300's to bring back a member of their team who preceded them and didn't return. Once they're zapped to the distant past, the rest of the narrative is basically a drawn out action sequence. For page after page the protagonists are either being chased or else involved in a sword fight before going back to running for their lives. Meanwhile in the present, the time travel technology is damaged in an accident. Technicians race to fix it in time to bring the historians, if they survive their adventure, back to the modern world. I was not on the edge of my seat. In large part this was because I didn't really care about any of the characters. As for the guy in charge of the technology company, of course he's a greedy jerk who is far less interested in who happens to live or die than in eventually monetizing the miracle machine. Bringing the past (specifically ferocious dinosaurs who roamed the earth) into the present intrigued me more as a premise in Jurassic Park than did bringing people from the present into the past as takes place in Timeline. In large part that is because dinosaurs are really cool so a book that provides them is way cooler than one which does not. But another part of the equation is that I am not the same reader that I used to be. Had I read Timeline around the same time as I read other Crichton books along with blockbuster page turners in the 80's and 90's by authors like Sheldon and Cook, would I have enjoyed it considerably more than the 2023 version of myself? Maybe. Or maybe I should stick with my current go-to author of blockbusters, Dan Brown. Some writing ages better than others. I picked Timeline up at a bookstore that I visited while on vacation on Long Beach Island. Upon seeing Crichton's name on the cover, a wave of nostalgia urged me to take a trip back in time. Timeline didn't do it for me, but your own reading experience may differ. If I ever watch the movie, I wouldn't be surprised if it's one of the infrequent occasions where I prefer the film to the novel since it is such a visual story. The book does feature a scattering of drawings throughout to help readers visualize the setting, for what it's worth. If time travel is one of your favorite tropes, Timeline may be a book for you. But if you want my time travel story recommendation, I would suggest reading Octavia Butler's Kindred or rewatching Back to the Future instead. The former finally made it to the screen recently and the latter is now on Broadway. What a time!...more

author: Hannah, Kristin*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: If you've ever watched a World War II movie then you've no doubt seen depictions of evil Nazi men and heroic men of the allied forces who fought in onIf you've ever watched a World War II movie then you've no doubt seen depictions of evil Nazi men and heroic men of the allied forces who fought in one way or another to keep Hitler from taking over the world. The Nightingale is an exceptional, hefty novel about German occupation of France during the war that centers on the heroism of French women. Two in particular, sisters Isabelle and Vianne. Isabelle is the more bad ass of the two, not content to sit at home and wait to be saved when she can go out and do some saving of her own. Not feeling particularly doted upon by her father (who never recovered from the previous war that he fought in, or the loss of his wife, so he drinks heavily in place of being a parent), Isabelle feels free of entanglement and lives as if she has nothing to lose. Vianne has a young daughter in her care, so she is not able to be as reckless as her sister. Isabelle joins of group of rebels that help the cause of defeating Germany any way they can, such as escorting to safety various pilots who survive their planes being brought down by the German military. Vianne's husband leaves to fight in the war and is captured. This leaves her and their daughter Sophie on their own, until a German soldier moves in to their home because as conquerors they can do whatever they want and French citizens must bear it the best they can. The soldier is a fairly decent man, all things considered. But when he is on the verge of finding the pilot that Isabelle has brought to temporarily hide on the property, Isabelle shoots him while Vianne goes upside his head with a shovel. His death, which of course they must hide, leads to a new German soldier being billeted in Vianne's home. This one is far less decent. The Nightingale is a big book and A LOT of stuff takes place. Its narrative goes back and forth between Isabelle's exploits that earn her the code name the Nightingale (including falling in love with a fellow rebel) and Vianne's struggle to survive Nazi occupation of her town and home, and risking her safety by bringing Jewish children to shelter. Then there is a third thread that is visited less frequently. In it the narrative jumps forward to 1995. An elderly woman who recently moved into an assisted living complex has been diagnosed with a return of cancer. She has been invited to an event in France. We understand that this woman must be one of the sisters, but we don't know which one. This is a secret for us to find out in the book's final pages. She tries to take the trip secretly but her son is on to her, while also knowing little to nothing about her heroic past. In France for the first time, he finally learns when people who are indebted to the sisters pay homage to them, about the extraordinary feats of his mother and aunt during the war. He finds out that as much as he thought he knew his mother, she is largely unknown to him. Now he will begin to learn much of the history, though probably not all on account of a major reason that I won't spoil, of two incredible women who fought tooth and nail to preserve their own lives while also saving those of many others. Thanks to the moving prose of Kristin Hannah, we readers are led to think of the hell that is war in ways that may not have occurred to us before - starting with realization that the MEN at the front were not the only brave souls who fought and killed and died for a righteous cause. Not by a long shot. I highly recommend this novel. The writing is not quite on the level of All the Light We Cannot See, another novel about German occupation of France during World War II. But be that as it may, Kristin Hannah definitely proves herself talented enough to provide a gripping tale that readers will not easily forget....more

title: The Weight of Water
author: Shreve, Anita
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The Weight of Water by Anita Shreve is a master class in slow and steady build up, constructed in highly detailed fashion that explores the seemingly The Weight of Water by Anita Shreve is a master class in slow and steady build up, constructed in highly detailed fashion that explores the seemingly mundane lives of unexceptional people, leading up to tragedy and shocking revelations. It accomplishes this feat in two for the price of one style, telling dual stories that are set a century apart. Shreve seamlessly guides the narrative back and forth. I marveled at the skill of the transitions. I have read a number of novels that tell parallel stories set in different time periods that are related to each other in some critical way. Commonly the portions are separated by chapters or sections. But Shreve virtually tells two stories simultaneously - a pretty neat trick. From one sentence to the next we go from the inner thoughts of Jean in 1995 to those of Maren in the 1800's. Jean is a photographer who is visiting Smuttynose Island, off the coast of Maine, to research murders that took place there well before she was born. Accompanying Jean are her husband and young daughter, plus her husband's brother and his girlfriend. The group is staying on a boat owned by her husband's brother, putting them in close proximity to the scene of the old crime where two women were killed in gruesome fashion and a man was given the death penalty after being convicted of the murders. Along with taking photographs of the area, Jean finds and steals documents from a local library relevant to the story she is researching. They are letters written by a woman who survived the night of the murders, and a translation of her recollections from Norwegian to English. As we read through the pages of The Weight of Water we learn about Jean, the backstory that led her to meet and marry a poet named Thomas, a marriage that we can see from the start is a troubled one precariously held together by their daughter. We also learn through the stolen pages that Jean is reading about Maren, her life in Norway marked by the early death of her mother, and her sudden decision to agree to marry the man who brings her to America in hopes of finding more bountiful waters to fish in. A crowded home in a new country comes to house not only she and her husband, but also her sister and their brother and his newlywed wife and the border who is eventually convicted for the brutal murders of Maren's sister and sister-in-law. I will refrain from delving further into the two plotlines in order to avoid straying into spoiler territory. Instead I will remark upon Shreve's incisive prose that brings us into two worlds set in the same desolate place. Heaviness lies in the hearts of both Jean and Maren for different sets of reasons. One is consumed by guilt and the other by suspicion. Both face problematic desires. Both women manage to survive while others around them do not. This is not to say though that they are especially alike, or their circumstances particularly similar. Yet Anita Shreve deftly intertwines their story arcs so that one begins where the other ends and the pattern keeps repeating, washing over us like the ebb and flow of the ocean over a rocky beach. After reading this book I discovered that the double murder portion of the story which is set in the 1800's is based on a true crime. Shreve comes up with a motive for her novel. This has been done before and will be done again by writers of fiction that re-imagines reality. The weight of masterful prose causes written words to sink into our skin and remain with us long after the reading is done with....more

title: The Story of a Shipwrecked Sailor
author: García Márquez, Gabriel
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: If you're looking for a read that is as exceptional as it is quick, and by quick I mean it can be read easily enough in a single sitting, then look noIf you're looking for a read that is as exceptional as it is quick, and by quick I mean it can be read easily enough in a single sitting, then look no further than The Story of a Shipwrecked Sailor. Gabriel Garcia Marquez sits at the top of the pyramid I've been constructing throughout the course of my reading life as the most gifted of wordsmiths. I consider Love in the Time of Cholera to be the most magnificently written novel of all time. The fact that it is a rather polarizing book, because what one reader translates as the purest form of romantic love another reader can understandably interpret as a treatise on the art of stalking, only adds to its charm for me. Whenever some literary canon maker puts out a list of the greatest novels ever written, it is common for Gabriel Garcia Marquez to be seated at the very top. The book awarded this position most often is not Love in the Time of Cholera, but rather, One Hundred Years of Solitude. I was blown away by that Marquez masterpiece as well, but Cholera remains my personal favorite. He is not only the king of long and winding epic novels such as those two, but also a master of brevity who has gifted us with succinct gems such as Chronicle of a Death Foretold and Memories of My Melancholy Whores. The titles of his stories alone are like little poems. Not long ago my wife gifted me with a copy of The Story of a Shipwrecked Sailor, which is a work of non-fiction. The vast majority of my reading attention is dedicated to fiction, but I do take detours into the world of memoirs and biographies and other forms of non-fiction from time to time, and diving into the prose of Gabriel Garcia Marquez is the very best reason for such a detour. Before Marquez became a celebrated novelist, he was a journalist who wrote for a newspaper in Colombia. It was during this time, before he had reached the age of thirty, when this true story fell into his lap. The title tells us much of what needs to be known. To flesh out the synopsis, in 1955 a military destroyer ship named the Caladas that had an 8-member crew was washed over by overpowering waves while taking what was supposed to be a routine trip from Alabama back to Colombia. Seven of the crew members drowned, one was able to get to a raft. This book is the story of the lone survivor. For the next ten days after going overboard, without food or water, accompanied only by birds and sharks that paid him periodic visits, the sailor fought to stay alive and maintain sanity while hoping to be rescued. During this time he was presumed dead along with the others and a funeral was held for him. Much to everyone's surprise, ten days after the Caladas was capsized, Luis Alejandro Velasco turned up on a deserted beach in northern Colombia. He was beaten and battered and sun baked and starving - and still very much alive. Marquez wrote Velasco's story as a series of articles that appeared in his newspaper over fourteen consecutive days, four days longer than the amount spent by Velasco alone at sea. Publication of the articles turned out to be problematic because the official government explanation for the Caladas going down was a storm, when in fact there was no storm, and the reason seven men lost their lives was because the Navy ship was overloaded with contraband. Years later when Marquez had become a celebrated author, the articles were assembled into a single little book. The story that unfolds over about a hundred pages is fascinating for three reasons. One - Marquez is a tremendously gifted writer. Two - He made the brilliant decision to write the articles which eventually became a book in first person point of view narration from the perspective of Velasco. The original 14 articles were actually credited to Velasco, with the role of Marquez not fully acknowledged until 15 years later. Three - Fighting against the elements and the natural erosion of one's body as time elapses without sufficient nutrition and shelter naturally makes for compelling storytelling. A man alone on a raft for ten days, assumed dead and seemingly on his way to making the assumption come true, fighting for survival with all of the wits and strength both physical and mental at his disposal, is page turner material no matter who is telling the story. Put such a story in the hands Gabriel Garcia Marquez and what you get is this literary marvel. I ended up with a copy of it because my wife visited a nearby Barnes & Noble that was going out of business, so there were deep discounts on the books they still had on hand. B&N, like bookstores in general, has been enduring a drawn out battle for survival much like the shipwrecked sailor. And like the sailor, against all odds, they appear at least for now to have made their way to a foothold on dry land. It seems (fingers crossed while knocking on wood) that B&N along with many independent bookstores will continue on after being considered dead. Whether it's the emergence of e-books or ending up alone in the middle of the ocean with nothing but the clothes on your back and shoes on your feet and the watch on your wrist, whatever doesn't kill you makes you stronger. Books and humans both have tremendous will to survive no matter how bleak the landscape is. I continue to root for both of us. We need each other....more

title: The Plot
author: Korelitz, Jean Hanff*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: You see a book with a title like 'The Plot' and of course the first question that springs to mind is "what is its plot?". Jean Hanff Korelitz wrote a You see a book with a title like 'The Plot' and of course the first question that springs to mind is "what is its plot?". Jean Hanff Korelitz wrote a greased lightning page turner about the writing process, one that most readers will relish and fellow writers will devour. It's about an author turned writing professor turned freelance editor for hire because after his debut novel is a success by many of the metrics that writers aspire to achieve, it fails to lead to a lucrative writing career. Subsequent efforts by Jake are considerably less lauded than book #1. While working at his second career as a writing professor at a small college named Ripley, which like Jake is also on a downward slope, he has a student one semester named Evan Parker who will come to change his life. While the failing trajectory of the school is irreversible, Jake has a reversal of fortune in store for him. That is because Evan reveals the plot of the book he's writing to his professor. The cocky student claims to be working on a surefire hit, guaranteed to become a Best Seller, land him on Oprah's couch, get a movie adaptation with an A-list Hollywood director, etc. etc. It doesn't even need to be written by anyone particularly talented at writing. The ingenuity of the plot alone will guarantee its golden fate. After being coaxed to not only produce sample pages of what he has written so far but also to reveal the plot of his work in progress, Jake must admit to himself, though not to his smug student who excels at being unlikable, that the story does indeed sound like a can't miss literary phenomenon. Several years pass, Jake has moved on to the freelance editing stage with reasonable doubt that an ongoing career as a traditionally published author is behind him, when he learns that his former student died not very long after taking his class. The legacy left behind by Evan is that of a Tavern owner rather than an enormously successful author. The book that was supposed to be a bonafide hit has not been published, perhaps was not even written beyond the small portion of the first draft that Jake critiqued years earlier. What is Jake to do with this information and his particular skill set? Just what you might expect. He writes the book himself, which is not to say he plagiarizes it since other than his memory of the sample chapter and a verbal plot synopsis, he has nothing to work from but his own talent. That plus a plot with such a clever twist that all the glory to come from multiple print runs and weeks spent perched atop Best Seller lists is a certainty. It doesn't even need to be particularly well written, but since Jake happens to be an excellent writer once he has the right plot at his disposal, Crib is every bit the success story that it was promised to be. As his rejuvenated writing career reaches the stratosphere, lucky breaks continue to come his way when he meets a beautiful woman destined to quickly become his girlfriend and then his wife. It is all too good to be true, and sure enough, the balloon is popped when Jake receives the first of what will be many menacing notes. The anonymous sender knows that Jake is not the one who came up with the plot of the book that readers can't get enough of. Jake has been found out, though not by Evan who is no longer living, so presumably by someone who knew Evan. Someone who does not appreciate that Evan's story was stolen by Jake. Someone who for unknown reasons wants Jake to confess or else...or else Jake's life will be made hell in incremental degrees unless he figures out who is tormenting him...and how to go about stopping it. After all, he is not a bad guy. He did what any writer would have done. He wrote a book that basically demanded to be written, and there was nothing that Evan could do about it any more, but there was something that Jake could do. Why deprive the world of a fantastic story when you are capable of bringing it to light? It's not stealing if nobody misses what has been taken. No great plot comes without great cost in the world according to Jean Hanff Korelitz's highly enjoyable novel. My only complaint, if that is the right word and I'm not entirely sure about that, is that I was able to correctly guess the ending. Along with being a fine novel about writers and writing, at its core The Plot is a mystery. For me, the best mysteries are those where the author leaves enough clues that it is possible for an attentive reader to solve it, yet they are unable to because of the subterfuge and misdirection surrounding those clues. If I fail to glean whodunnit (and sometimes also how and why they dunnit) because the author does not provide sufficient clues, making it impossible to figure out until all is revealed at the end, such a book is disqualified from being considered one of the best mysteries I've read even if overall I enjoyed it. When I AM able to figure out what's going on such as was the case with The Plot, I'm pleased with my skills of detection but slightly disappointed that the author failed to "get me". Or course, a great many novels are mysteries even if they don't technically fall into the genre. If unlike me you favor formulaic books where you know in advance how things will work out because that is what the formula dictates, that's another story. But non-formulaic books, whether they be a thriller or literary fiction or science fiction or fantasy or horror or whatever the case may be, are all mysteries at heart in that we readers go in knowing just an outline of the story (assuming that we read the cover copy or an online synopsis), and we need to experience the full book in order for all of its truths to be revealed. Readers like myself pick a novel up because we want to be enlightened and surprised by it. I greatly enjoyed The Plot and did find it to be enlightening, but the twist in the plot of The Plot failed to catch me off guard. Nevertheless I do highly recommend it, especially for those who like books about books, about writers, about that highly exasperating art form known as writing, and then beyond it to the experience of being published to acclaim, or published but nobody cares and very few read it. Another fine novel that contains a fictional story written by an author within the fictional story that we are reading is Tony and Susan by Austin Wright. You can find my  of it here at goodreads. I still have not gotten around to watching the movie adaptation of it that is called Nocturnal Animals. I couldn't help being reminded of Tony and Susan while reading The Plot, comparing and contrasting them. Consider them both to be highly recommended by me. One crucial difference between them that I'll note is that while the story within the story of Tony and Susan is edge of your seat material, the storyline outside of the manuscript that a character has written is relatively low stakes and low key. In The Plot, both the inner plot and the outer plot quicken the pulse and have you rushing to get to get to the next chapter of either one....more

title: Before the Fall
author: Hawley, Noah*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Before the Fall by Noah Hawley is a well constructed, absorbing read. There are books that I meander through, taking my time to fall under the spell, Before the Fall by Noah Hawley is a well constructed, absorbing read. There are books that I meander through, taking my time to fall under the spell, willing to take breaks of a day or two if busy with other life chores before getting back to reading. And then there are books like this one that I plow through, chomping at the bit to get back to it during the non-reading portion of my day. This has more to do with the nature of the story than the quality of writing. If a book is a thriller with a mystery to be resolved, natural curiosity is a compelling force. This can backfire on a book though, because the more anxious I am to see how an author has resolved a riddle, the more disappointed I may be in the end if I find it to be underwhelming. Conversely, if a book is more about the journey than the destination then I'm less likely to be a dissatisfied by non-explosive final pages. Authors have a Catch-22 on their hands in that the more cats they murder with generated curiosity, the greater the potential for let-down is if the ending fails to deliver on a riveting build up. If you peruse the backlist of videos on this channel you'll find some examples of books that I raced through only to be left wanting at their conclusions. That's a ME thing. Other readers, most especially those who frequently dive into series rather than stand-alone titles, appreciate being left hanging by endings that are not entirely resolved because that means they get to continue on with the literary adventure in subsequent books. I tend to gravitate towards novels that wrap things up within the covers of a single volume, and when there is a puzzle to piece together, I'm picky about what I find to be satisfying resolution. In the case of Before The Fall, I have no complaints. That may be because even though it is a very suspenseful novel with a mystery at its core, the story is less about Who Did What and the Reasons Why then it is a meditation on blind twists of fate that defy any explanation beyond "shit happens arbitrarily". But don't let my use of the word "meditation" lead you to believe that Before the Fall is long on philosophical introspection and short on action. It isn't. It's a masterful blend of both by an author who also toils as a storyteller for television and movies, so he knows well that it's critical for a story to be compelling enough to keep the audience in their seats. The mystery of Before the Fall is laid out in its opening pages. A private jet containing two wealthy couples taking a short trip from Martha's Vineyard to New York crashes into the ocean sixteen minutes into the flight. One of the men runs a conservative news network - a fictional Fox News. The other is a high level financial investor who it turns out is laundering money for foreign countries that are on America's naughty list. So long as he is making plenty of profit for others as well as himself, he could care less if his efforts happen to aid terrorists. As result, he learns shortly before embarking on the flight that his company is under investigation and the empire he has built may soon come tumbling down. Since he works for dangerous people, there is reason to suspect that the plane crash may have been caused by someone with an axe to grind against Ben Kipling. Or maybe the target of ire was David Bateman on account of the political spin of his television network. Or maybe it was mechanical error rather than sinister activity, though initial reports indicate that the plane was functioning properly before its sudden plunge. The crash takes the lives of both couples, the pilots and crew members, and the young daughter of David and Maggie Bateman. There are two improbable survivors. One is a painter named Scott Burroughs who is not rich and powerful like the other passengers. He is an affable fellow who does okay with the ladies and is determined to focus more on his art career and less on drinking his potential away. He scored an invite by befriending Maggie who he often runs into at the farmer's market. Is there more to their relationship than meets the eye? If so, can that possibly have something to do with the cause of the plane crash? Along with being a talented artist who happens to specialize in paintings of disaster scenes (tornadoes, train derailments, and even a plane crash), Scott is also an exceptional swimmer. This is how he manages, after not being killed immediately on impact, to swim several miles of ocean to safety. He does so not on his own but tugging the only other survivor, the Bateman's 4-year old son, forging a lifelong connection between rescuer and rescued. The narrative jumps back and forth between events before the crash and after, and the point of view switches among various characters to flesh out critical back stories. Among these other characters is one of the men investigating the crash, and also Bill Cunningham, the main news anchor at the Bateman's TV network who is determined to find a scapegoat (Scott being his primary candidate) and get the big scoop by any unethical means necessary. Then there's Maggie's sister who finds herself with an orphaned nephew to raise and a very large inheritance to manage until the boy comes of age, plus with the man that she is unhappily married to. Ultimately the narrative centers on Scott as he tries to adapt to a life turned upside down, one day a nobody, the next day a paparazzi hounded hero, and the next - the lead suspect of a horrific crime if a crime is what it is. We readers know that Scott is an imperfect but innocent man. What we don't know is what or who it is that caused the plane crash. Over the novel's pages we learn bit by bit what took place before and led up to the tragic fall from the sky. Very well done by Noah Hawley. He kept me on the edge of my seat with an intriguing premise and kept my attention rooted with skillfully rendered prose....more

title: Harlem Shuffle        (Ray Carney, #1)
author: Whitehead, Colson*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I have read nearly all of Colson Whitehead's books. After reading his latest I believe there are only two or three titles in his backlist that I havenI have read nearly all of Colson Whitehead's books. After reading his latest I believe there are only two or three titles in his backlist that I haven't gotten to. One thing that you know you'll get from his work is excellent, addictive writing. Whether it's a work of literary fiction, a book so full of personal details that it reads like a memoir, an actual memoir, a novel based on true life events, speculative in nature, or an unexpected dip into the genre of zombie lit (Zone One happens to be one of his books that I haven't read yet), you know you're getting quality prose from Mr. Whitehead. If you were a stranger to his work and Harlem Shuffle was the first book of his that you picked up, a glance at the cover copy where the most notable literary awards that have been given to him are listed would inform you that you're about to read something by a critic's darling. Harlem Shuffle did not disappoint. It was much more casual in tone than the last two Whitehead novels I read - his back to back Pulitzer Prize winners 'The Underground Railroad' and 'The Nickel Boys'. I suspect that another author will win the Pulitzer for Fiction next go around, but that's by no means a knock on Harlem Shuffle's merits. This novel follows the exploits of a man named Ray Carney throughout the 1960's. Ray is a Black man, he lives in Harlem of course (which is obvious because of the book's title, not because of the main character's race) and he is the son of a criminal. Ray steps away from his deceased father's legacy by becoming a legitimate businessman, owning a furniture store. He also spends time in his father's shadow due to illegal side business that comes into his shop from time to time. If someone brings a stolen item to Ray, he has the connections to find a buyer for it. Ray's ambitions mostly lie on the legitimate side of his dual existence. He wants to enlarge the size of his store. He wants to sell upscale merchandise from the "Whites Only" domain, even if many of his customers would need to purchase it on layaway. Ray wants to move to a more upscale neighborhood like Riverside Drive, and perhaps someday down the line, to the legendary Striver's Row of Harlem, NY. Ray Carney is a striver personified, never mind that his wife's parents look down on him because they come from older money while Ray is just one generation removed from hood life. Ray was able to get started on the straight and narrow after surprisingly finding money gained from his father's illegal activities in the truck inherited from his dad. But it doesn't matter how you got started so much as what you do once you get there. Among Ray's goals is entry into an exclusive club for Harlem's Black elite called The Dumas Club. His father-in-law belongs to it, which perhaps makes up for the fact that his flesh and blood father was a criminal who only would have gotten into The Dumas Club if he was robbing it. Ray's initial application to the club is rejected, never mind that the bribe money he paid to improve his chances was accepted. Being a striver, there's always another opportunity somewhere down the line, even if you have to get down and dirty to create that opportunity. The only thing that endangers Ray Carney's relentless forward progress is his cousin Freddie. They were raised like brothers, but since Freddie didn't luck into finding a bundle of cash like Ray did, Freddie makes no attempts at being an upstanding citizen who honestly earns a hard day's pay. He is always on the look-out for the next score along with his next drug high. And since he knows that his cousin has useful contacts when it comes to moving stolen goods, whenever he shows up it's usually to get Ray involved in criminal activity. Since Ray feels obligated to help out his cousin, and because he is his father's son as much as he is his own very different sort of man, Ray allows himself to be drawn in despite the jeopardy that it puts his conventional, above board lifestyle into. Even if inclined to walk away from an illicit opportunity, once dangerous individuals assume that you're involved based on your history, there isn't much difference between actively seeking out trouble and trouble looking for you. Ray Carney is basically a good man who keeps hustling out in the open as well as on the down low, striving to make his grass is always greener dreams come true, moving along with the changing times amid the Harlem shuffle. I highly recommend this novel. I have no idea what Colson Whitehead's next book will be about because like Ray Carney he keeps it moving, always searching for uncharted territory to explore. Some people have favorite writers because those authors consistently deliver a similar brand of literary treat over and over. Perhaps they stick to a particular genre, or if they stray a bit, they repeatedly examine particular tropes and write about the same types of people consistently. This is neither an attribute or a flaw. It just is. Colson Whitehead is one of MY favorite authors for the opposite reason. I never know what he's going to come up with next, but chances are that it won't feel like an echo of his previous books. It will be its own thing, and the common thread between the works of Colson Whitehead, from my least to my most favorite, is the excellence....more

title: The Paris Bookseller
author: Maher, Kerri*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The Paris Bookseller by Kerri Maher is a work of historical fiction centered on the life of Sylvia Beach. If you don't already know, in 1919 Sylvia BeThe Paris Bookseller by Kerri Maher is a work of historical fiction centered on the life of Sylvia Beach. If you don't already know, in 1919 Sylvia Beach founded the original Shakespeare and Company bookstore in Paris, France. The bookshop of this name that some of you may have visited in more recent years opened in 1951 and repurposed the name of Beach's iconic store as tribute in 1964. If like myself you are endlessly fascinated with the artists of The Lost Generation then you'll want to add Kerri Maher's lovingly researched novel to your book pile. To quote Wikipedia rather than trying to put it into my own words - The Lost Generation was the social generational cohort that was in early adulthood during World War I. "Lost" in this context refers to the "disoriented, wandering, directionless" spirit of many of the war's survivors in the early postwar period. The term is also particularly used to refer to a group of American expatriate writers living in Paris during the 1920s. Gertrude Stein is credited with coining the term, and it was subsequently popularized by Ernest Hemingway who used it in the epigraph for his 1926 novel The Sun Also Rises: "You are all a lost generation". Well said Wikipedia. Among the notable figures of this period who populate the pages of The Paris Bookseller along with Hemingway and his alternating romantic partners are Gertrude Stein, F. Scott Fitzgerald and Zelda Fitzgerald, T.S. Eliot, Ezra Pound, John Dos Passos, Sherwood Anderson, Ford Madox Ford and most prominently - James Joyce. Along with the "Lost Generation" writers, let me not leave off painters name dropped in The Paris Bookseller who came to prominence during this period such as Matisse and Picasso. Authors like Henry Miller, William Faulkner and Virginia Woolf are also mentioned in passing, even if they didn't happen to be among the American expatriates who felt stifled by the conservative attitudes of America and so came to Paris where for a time they could live their best lives and produce their best art and spend plenty of time hanging out at the hippest bookstore on the planet. Contrast Prohibition taking place in America with drinking wine or perhaps even a sip of absinthe in France. Another prominent figure of this time and in this novel and in the life of Sylvia Beach is her longtime romantic partner, Adrienne Monnier. Before there was a Shakespeare and Company, Adrienne was a trailblazing businesswoman who opened the bookshop and lending library, "La Maison des Amis des Livres". Shakespeare and Company would eventually move across the street, with Adrienne's shop providing books written in French while Sylvia's shop serviced those in search of English-language books. As with Adrienne's shop, Shakespeare and Company served as a lending library along with having books for sale. If you seek works about notable women who enhanced the cause of feminism, The Paris Bookseller will scratch that itch. The same can be said if you are interested in stories about notable lesbians. Paris in the 1920's was more liberal than America when it came to living and let live in this regard as well. With talk of the US Supreme Court taking away the reproductive rights of American women here in 2022, once again American conservatism rears its head. With war being waged on Ukraine by Russia, one wonders if this conflict will spill to other lands and how many casualties and tortured aftermaths will result. Will we soon have a new Lost Generation in search of a new nirvana to escape to? History does love to repeat itself. Adrienne and Sylvia (plus Gertrude Stein) are women well worth knowing more about, and you may care to check out my  of Z: A Novel of Zelda Fitzgerald by Therese Anne Fowler. Zelda is only mentioned in passing in The Paris Bookseller which focuses primarily on the life of Sylvia Beach. That life was dominated by the presence of Adrienne Monnier and perhaps even more so by one of the writers I mentioned earlier - James Joyce. While a woman opening an English-language bookshop in Paris was a pretty big deal in 1919, the event that put Shakespeare and Company on the literary map for all time was Sylvia Beach's decision to publish James Joyce's controversial novel, Ulysses in 1922. Considered obscene by those who couldn't look past its strong language to appreciate the novelty and beauty of its prose, Ulysses needed someone brave and resourceful enough to bring it to the light of day. By publishing the one and only book under the bookstore's imprint, the course of literary history was altered. We readers have a comfortable window seat view of the coolest place to be during one of the most artistically influential periods in history courtesy of Kerri Maher's steady handed prose. There isn't much in the way of tension until the latter section of The Paris Bookseller when multiple editions of Ulysses have been published and it looks as if America will finally be open to embracing it. For the book to become available worldwide it needs a major publisher behind it such as Random House, run at the time by Bennet Cerf. James Joyce is anxious for this to happen whereas Sylvia Beach is loathe to relinquish control of the work that she dedicated so much time and effort to birthing when nobody else was willing to touch it with a ten foot pole. The warmth of their personal relationship is greatly tested as Joyce intensifies his badgering over the fate of a book that means the world to both of them. As the author, Ulysses is James Joyce's baby. As the publisher, Ulysses is Sylvia Beach's baby. Something and someone has to give. I know I'm not the only one with a weakness for stories about writers and the writing process. The publishing process is a related endeavor of course, one that at times can resemble a battlefield. If these are areas of interest to you, The Paris Bookseller will be right up your alley. If you could care less about this sort of stuff, perhaps preferring steamy romances or out of this world science fiction or edge of your seat thrillers or terrifying tales of horror featuring paranormal beings or inhuman humans, then you may find The Paris Bookseller to be insufficiently eventful and I wouldn't steer you towards it. But if you're like the character played by Owen Wilson in Woody Allen's cinematic gem Midnight in Paris, looking to escape into days of yesteryear where the person in the cafe seat to your right is destined for immortality, as is the person to your immediate left, then I encourage you to dive into the world of Kerri Maher's The Paris Bookseller. Now that I'm done with it, I'm itching to read Hemingway's A Moveable Feast for a real time non-fictionalized take on Paris in the 20's. Or perhaps a reread of my favorite Hemingway novel "The Sun Also Rises" is in order. If not my very next read, then soon enough....more
