title: Slam
author: Hornby, Nick
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Another Nick Hornby book polished off. This particular one, Slam, is as Nick Hornby-esque as the rest of them. By that I mean that it's easy to read, Another Nick Hornby book polished off. This particular one, Slam, is as Nick Hornby-esque as the rest of them. By that I mean that it's easy to read, likeable characters are contained within, observations about the human condition are made in wry fashion, I smiled throughout the turn of pages at his flair for comedic touches, and then it was done and I found myself thinking that while it was all pleasant enough, I didn't like it quite as much as the film adaptations of High Fidelity or About a Boy. I did like Slam more than other Hornby novels I've read such as A Long Way Down and How to be Good. I didn't enjoy it quite as much as Juliet, Naked. Slam ends up somewhere in the middle of my personal list of Hornby reads. It is about a high school boy who gets his girlfriend pregnant, and she plans to have and keep the baby. This of course has significant impact on both of their lives as well as the family members that they live with. The story is told from Sam's point of view rather than Alicia's, so once again we have a Nick Hornby tale that's "about a boy". Instead of having a suicidal mother such as was the protagonist's situation in that story, Sam has to deal with fatherhood way way earlier than planned. Instead of meeting a nice bloke pretending to be his father who buys him a pair of trainers and joins him onstage to share the spotlight of humiliation, Sam has a poster of the skateboard maestro Tony Hawk. Serving basically as a Bible for Sam is the book that Tony Hawk wrote about his life. It holds all the wisdom that Sam finds himself needing no matter how dire circumstances appear to be, or so Sam believes. The only other thing I find worth noting about the rather straightforward plot of Slam is that Sam finds himself transported a few months to a couple years into the future every now and again. This gives him foresight that may elude you and I, since he has a general idea how things are going to work out for him even though his lucid dreams do omit a few details that won't get cleared up until his future actually arrives. Hornby always writes with expert charm and we readers root for things to work out for his protagonists as they navigate whatever it is that Hornby gives them to deal with. Along the way love is lost and found or the other way around, insights are reached which add to depth of maturity, and then we reach the final page and go about our way. There is a relatively low number of authors that I have read three or more novels by. Perhaps one day I'll compile that list to see how many there are. What these authors have in common is that they have something to say about the world and a way of saying it that appeals to me. Either that or I just find them plain entertaining even if not particularly profound. Hornby is halfway in one camp and halfway in the other. So don't be surprised if you eventually stumble upon a  of yet another Nick Hornby novel that I decide to check out. Until then...happy reading....more

title: Finger Rhymes
author: Tetley, Nigel*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: How many utterly charming poems do you think can be written on the subject of the fingers at the end of your hands? Turns out the answer is at least aHow many utterly charming poems do you think can be written on the subject of the fingers at the end of your hands? Turns out the answer is at least a dozen, for that is what Nigel Tetley gives us in his delightful children's book - Finger Rhymes. Just as the title promises, this book is a collection of poetry on the theme of fingers. Each one is as sweet as the smile a child will give in response to them. Several compare the shape fingers can make to seemingly unrelated objects. Like magic a young child will realize in Playground Fingers that one finger can become a seesaw, two a slide, three a a teepee, four become rope swings, and five are a roundabout spun around on to great delight. In Green Fingers little gardeners discover that one finger is a slug, two a pair of shears, three a garden fork, four grooves in the soil, and five petals of a flower. Other poems bring children by the hand and imagination to the beach, helping out parents in the kitchen or with tailoring, a day at the beach, and a fireworks display. Each one shows the reader and the read-to that there are countless ways to look at the world, and at ourselves. Starting with the five fingers that we have on each hand. The clever poems are accompanied by wonderful illustrations done by Peter David Scott - realistically rendered with a retro feel to them. From my own ill-fated attempt at writing a rhyming board book years ago, I know that maintaining a steady cadence when composing sound-alike sentences is trickier than one might think. Nigel Tetley nails each poem with a snap of his talented fingers. If you're in search of a gift for a child still being read to or perhaps just starting out with reading for themselves, I highly recommend Finger Rhymes....more

title: The Club Dumas
author: Pérez-Reverte, Arturo
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The Club Dumas is an absorbing read particularly if you have interest in the topics of the occult, the life and writings of Alexandre Dumas (particulaThe Club Dumas is an absorbing read particularly if you have interest in the topics of the occult, the life and writings of Alexandre Dumas (particularly The Three Musketeers), and perhaps most of all - the early history of book producing. I'm talking way back when books were not mass produced, certainly not on-demand on a digital press, but instead lovingly created with the finest of materials that were built to last. The main character of The Club Dumas, a man named Corso, is a rare book finder for hire. If you're a rich collector looking for a 1st edition copy of a book printed and bound centuries ago - Corso is your guy to track it down and obtain it by any means you're willing to pay for. There is a dual track of investigation going on in The Club Dumas. One has to do with locating the three known copies of a book entitled The Nine Doors. Allegedly this book can be used by someone who can figure out how to properly read it to summon Satan and be granted whatever is desired - at the cost of your soul for eternal damnation, of course. But in the process of tracking down these books, Corso keeps encountering people who appear to have been lifted right off the pages of The Three Musketeers. Clues suggest that Dumas perhaps sold his soul in exchange for the literary acclaim and riches and life of debauchery that he enjoyed prior to eventually dying penniless, but with his name living on forever due to publications such as Musketeers and The Count of Monte Cristo. I have yet to read the former and just recently read Monte Cristo for the first time. Dumas is an interesting figure in literature, made even more interesting (to me anyway) upon learning that he was of mixed race. Typically if you're reading a book from the 1800's, published serially or otherwise, for a class or perhaps for pleasure, you're reading the work of a White author. Alexandre Dumas is an exception who had cream in his coffee - or vice versa. I digress as I love to do. The atmosphere of Arturo Perez-Reverte's novel is shrouded in literary fog from the opening pages (in which we learn that a book collector has been found hung to death: perhaps suicide, perhaps something more sinister) to the closing pages. In between we follow Corso around as he tracks down the three copies of The Nine Doors, doing his best to avoid and survive interruptions from curious characters who seem to have something to do with his quest. Among them are two women - one who fits the type that Alfred Hitchock loved to cast in his movies, the other improbably too young to be so improbably wise and so improbably proficient while being remarkably detached from the proceedings and ridiculously sexy. The latter woman is named after a character from the world of Sherlock Holmes, so she's borrowed from the fictional world of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle (which is one of my favorite places) rather than that of Alexandre Dumas. Pretty much every sentence describing either woman lustfully describes how sexy they both are. If that sort of thing annoys you, consider yourself warned. If a storyline that touches upon devil worship and sword wielding musketeers and Sherlock Holmes and the business of producing books without modern technology (or forging them in modern times with ingenuity and patience) - if you're a fan of books about books - then perhaps you'll forgive the women described largely as sex objects stuff. They do serve critical roles in the plot rather than simply being sexual conquests. But the repetition (we get it - she's hot!) and stilted nature of some of the dialogue made me give a 3-star rating instead of 4. This is yet another book that I would rate 3.5 if goodsreads provided a half-star option. Overall I really enjoyed The Club Dumas. I won't go into spoiler territory but will simply say that I found the ending to be both cleverly satisfying and a little less than what I hoped was being built up to. Apparently the movie The Ninth Gate starring Johnny Depp is loosely based on this novel. I'm not entirely certain but I think I've seen that movie and yet I didn't realize while reading The Club Dumas that it had anything to do with the movie. So either I haven't actually seen the movie yet or else the adaptation is so loose that there wasn't strong enough of a connection to make me realize I was reading a book that inspired a movie that I'd already seen. I now need to watch the movie, either for the first time or else again. But you came here for a book , not a film critique. Overall I was fully sucked into the universe of The Club Dumas. Give me a literary, historical mystery with otherworldly elements such as The Club Dumas and you'll hook me every time. I'm already looking forward to the next one, whatever it will be. Any suggestions?...more

title: The Jigsaw Man        (Inspector Anjelica Henley, #1)
author: Matheson, Nadine*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I was kinda chomping at the bit to read this book. I have a thing that I'm neither proud nor ashamed of for serial killer narratives. This interest prI was kinda chomping at the bit to read this book. I have a thing that I'm neither proud nor ashamed of for serial killer narratives. This interest primarily covers the category of true crime, whether it's a non-fiction book or a documentary or a screen version featuring actors playing the parts of killer and victims and cops determined to break the case. I am astounded by the levels of evil that mankind is capable of. Some of us close our eyes at the carnage while others can't look away. I'm in the second group. When skilled fiction writers decide to create a serial killer inspired by the real-life monsters who dwell among us, consider me intrigued. The fact that The Jigsaw Man, along with having a very cool title also happens to be written by a Black woman, raised my curiosity level another notch. If there are many other serial killer novels written by Black women authors, I've somehow missed the memo. Having recently watched the Netflix series Dahmer and the movie The Good Nurse (the latter being about Charles Cullen), I was primed to read this Nadine Matheson novel. It seems that The Jigsaw Man is meant to be the first in a series of books featuring Inspector Anjelica Henley. I favor standalone books over titles from a series as a general rule, in part because I don't want to feel that I need to read multiple books to get the whole story. But my number one reading rule is that I have no rules. If something about a story is intriguing to me, I'm willing to give it a shot. Ultimately, unfortunately, I was underwhelmed by The Jigsaw Man. This despite the fact that it features not one but two dueling serial killers, one a copycat of the other who is behind bars for his crimes. That is until he manages to escape in order to track down the killer who has greatly annoyed him rather than flattering him with imitation. And he also wants to mess with Anjelica Henley some more after nearly killing her when she stopped his original murder spree. Angelica bears physical scars from the knife that Peter Olivier plunged into her stomach, and psychological scars from the ordeal. They combined to temporarily push her out of the police force, and upon her return to a special unit that specializes in tracking down the most heinous killers, she is immediately on the trail of an unknown killer who is leaving body parts from dismembered victims in multiple locations throughout town. Rather than finding one corpse at a time, law enforcement finds a leg here, an arm there, the head over there. It's grizzly stuff for sure. But to be truly captivating, a book needs to do more than roll out a series of horiffic murders. It needs to make me care about some of the characters, or at least one of them at minimum. It needs to not only make readers curious about whodunnit and how they dunnit and why they dunnit, but to immerse you in a world that feels real. I have read a few crime novels that disappointed me with their ending, yet I still considered them to be excellent reads because the journey from premise to conclusion was well laid out. With The Jigsaw Man, I frequently found turns of events to be implausible. Why is this killer being treated like royalty by prison guards? How can security around such a notorious criminal be so lax? Don't expect me to buy 'budget cuts' as the explanation. How is this guy able to overwhelm everyone he encounters? Does nobody else know how to fight or use a weapon to defend themselves - not even trained police officers? As for the psychology behind character motivation, I found it less than compelling. Serial killers may kill for no better reasons than evil and envy and ego, but Inspector Henley will be the recurring character over however many of these books get published, so she is the character who should feel layered with complexities and contradictions and nuanced with traits which make us empathize and sympathize with her. Perhaps she will grow on me if I give her several books in the series to win me over. I won't rule that out. But it's also possible that this will be the only Nadine Matheson book I'll ever read. Some authors get just one shot to win me over. I see from s online that plenty others liked The Jigsaw Man considerably more than I did. I won't tell you to steer clear of it. Every book isn't for every reader. That is part of the fascination of literature....more

title: Tony and Susan
author: Wright, Austin
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Tony and Susan made for a riveting read. Or perhaps I should say, a riveting read within an excellent read. The unique premise provides a thriller ploTony and Susan made for a riveting read. Or perhaps I should say, a riveting read within an excellent read. The unique premise provides a thriller plot tucked inside a less pulse pounding work of literary fiction. The story that WE the readers are imbibing courtesy of author Austin Wright is about a woman named Susan who is married to a doctor who is out of town on business for the weekend. Their kids are home with her but serve exclusively as minor background noise. Since they're teens rather than toddlers, their needs don't need to be attended to by Susan. Since her husband does not make an appearance until the book's final pages, she doesn't need to attend to his his needs either. So it's just us and Susan. We learn that her 25-year old marriage to Arthur is her second one. Previously, and rather briefly, she was married to Edward. During the period of Susan's first marriage, Edward yearned to be a writer and is mostly trying to figure out how to go about that while also managing to be a breadwinner and reasonably tolerable person to be around. These things do not naturally go hand in hand. They put a strain on the marriage that ultimately leads Susan to have an affair with their neighbor Arthur. The cheating begins while Edward is out of town trying to write, something he hasn't mastered doing at home even though distractions there are minimal. Arthur is also married but his wife has gone off the deep end, about to be permanently committed to a mental institution. When the cats are away the mice have extramarital sex, or however it is that saying goes. Susan confesses to Edward, promises not to do it again, Edward sullenly accepts it while his insecurity reasonably grows to enormous proportions, and Susan eventually returns to screwing around with Arthur who doesn't have to bother hiding things from a wife gone mad. Edward eventually has enough of this arrangement and grants Susan a divorce. She moves on to lasting marriage number two with Arthur, and Edward also marries again with better luck the second go around. I should also mention that Susan and Edward grew up together, not only in the same neighborhood but in the same house because Susan's parents took him in after Edward is left parent-less. They have a strictly platonic relationship for years, basically siblings, then hook up as young adults and transition to a romantic one that is fated to fail. This information is all contained in the book that we are reading about Susan's life. But Susan has different reading material that we are also privy to, reading over her shoulder in essence. One day, a few months prior to the weekend when Arthur is out of town, hopefully not continuing to have sex with the mistress that he promised not to screw around with any more, Susan receives a package in the mail. It's the manuscript of a novel - the one that Edward has finally gotten around to writing. He wants to get his ex-wife's opinion on it for he has always valued her opinion if not her ability to remain faithful. In the letter that accompanies the manuscript, he writes that he'll be in town a few months down the road. Perhaps they can get together then, share a drink or meal, discuss his novel. Susan procrastinates and does not begin reading it until 3 days before Edward said he would be in town. Over those days, in a relatively quiet house with her husband out of town, Susan will read the manuscript so she'll have something to say about it when Edward presses for her opinion. So we the reader end up reading two books at once - the one about Susan entitled Tony and Susan - and the one written by Edward entitled Nocturnal Animals. The latter is the thriller I referenced earlier. It is a heart pounding page turner that's near impossible to put down. The only reason we ever do is when Austin Wright chooses to have Susan put it down to return us briefly to her world. Tony and Susan goes back and forth between itself and the novel it contains, with the latter being the one that truly has us hooked. All along I found myself wondering - why didn't Austin Wright simply write the novel that his character Edward wrote since that's the one we can't get enough of. What will be the dastardly connection finally made between the inner story and the outer story? Is Edward's manuscript perhaps an elaborate clue about something he has planned for Susan - some ridiculously long awaited payback for her infidelity? No way to know until we and Susan get through Edward's book and they then have their reunion - or so it seems. Nocturnal Animals (which is both the name of Edward's novel and the name of the film adaptation that I promised myself not to watch until reading Tony and Susan first) is about a middle aged man named Tony with a wife and young adult daughter. While driving to their summer house in Maine they end up getting into a confrontation with guys in two other cars driving on the same road in the hours between midnight and morning. They kidnap the man's wife and daughter, and the next day he learns that they raped and murdered his family. Will justice be served? If not justice from the legal system, will the math professor (perhaps a coincidental job allocation since Susan also teaches for a living - perhaps not) who finds himself suddenly without a wife and daughter (neither of whom is named Susan - the Susan that eventually shows up in Edward's novel is a minor, inconsequential character) settle for vengeance with the help of a twisted cop who worked on the case? Like Susan, we are fully absorbed in Nocturnal Animals. Unlike her, we aren't burdened with contemplating what Edward might be saying about us through his novel. I won't spoil the ending of either Tony and Susan or of Nocturnal Animals. I won't even hint at whether either story's ending floored or underwhelmed me - or perhaps lay somewhere in the middle. Judge for yourself if and when you choose to read Tony and Susan, which I do recommend doing. I'll conclude this  by stating that Austin Wright was a gifted writer who basically gave us two wonderful novels for the price of one - two books that aren't even the same genre. I enjoyed both stories contained within Tony and Susan. It's a book I won't easily forget -- AND a book I won't easily forget. This novel will especially resonate with anyone who has ever written a novel and worked up the nerve to ask a loved one to read it - OR - anyone who has ever been the loved one asked to read that book. What will be the right things to say about it? What will most definitely be the wrong things? Cross your fingers and hope it will be good enough for the necessity to lie to be kept minimal....more

title: Blonde
author: Oates, Joyce Carol
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Is Blonde a biography of Marilyn Monroe? Well no, technically it's a novel. Blonde is a thoroughly researched, masterfully written work of fiction aboIs Blonde a biography of Marilyn Monroe? Well no, technically it's a novel. Blonde is a thoroughly researched, masterfully written work of fiction about a lot of things that really happened to a person that everybody knows plenty about. Being one of the most famous people of all time, there is no shortage of material written about her extraordinary life. Her meteoric rise to Hollywood stardom (not just in her own time but for all time), as well as her tragic early death makes for irresistible subject matter. Along with that there is her riveting romantic life featuring high profile marriages to Joe DiMaggio and Arthur Miller plus a dalliance towards the end of her days with President Kennedy. Google "books about Marilyn Monroe" and a mile long list comes up featuring heavy hitter authors like Norman Mailer and Gloria Steinem. There's also MY STORY, written about Marilyn by Marilyn Monroe herself and Ben Hecht. Let us not forget the lovely song by Elton John that aptly describes her as a candle in the wind. Joyce Carol Oates perhaps takes the deepest creative dive into the world of Marilyn Monroe. The opening pages of Blonde take place when Norma Jean is a baby, and the book closes with dramatization of her final breaths. Since Oates chose to approach Marilyn's life through the lens of fiction writing, the blanks that lack firsthand witnesses to verify what was said and done and felt can be filled in. Mostly written from first person point of view, a window into Marilyn's thoughts and hopes and dreams is opened by Oates. What we readers see is a woman who led a glamorous existence, had many lovers even if not nearly enough love, and was on a lifelong search for the father she never knew and a quest to feel worthy of her mother's love. And while the world saw her as a blonde bombshell worthy of adoration for the gifts of her beauty and sex appeal, Marilyn saw herself as an artist desiring to expand her intellect and master her craft. On screen we see her being funny and vulnerable and dangerously unhinged and coy and innocent and naive and nurturing. Even those who have never seen one of her movies have superficial knowledge about the details of her brief time on earth. Surely you've seen the image of her skirt being blown up by air from a subway grating. You know that her name is synonymous with blonde haired, blue eyed variety of sex appeal. But perhaps you did not know that much of her childhood was spent in an orphanage because her mother was too mentally unstable to raise her. Perhaps you know of her marriages to one of the most famous baseball players ever along with one of America's greatest playwrights. But like me you may not have known about her first marriage that she entered as a teen after living in a foster home. The degree to which she was exploited by Hollywood power brokers who took advantage of her desire to be a movie star is heartbreaking revelation. Her unfulfilled desire to have and raise children meant that a happily ever after fairy tale ending kept eluding her, and so being the most desired woman in the world would be her consolation prize. Seeking validation from others is a guaranteed path to misery. Loving yourself for who you are does not come easily to everyone. What we all want is happiness, and the shape of particular sets of ambitions will cause people to chase after this or that or the other. Life teaches us all eventually that you can fail to achieve your goals but nonetheless be happy, and you can accomplish everything you dream of and still be a tortured soul. If Marilyn Monroe managed to secure more personal contentment, perhaps she would have acquired less fame and fanfare. Perhaps not. She had it all, including an abundance of insecurity and loneliness. When the spotlight was on, she dazzled viewers. When it was off, the character of Marilyn Monroe was put away and the reality of being Norman Jean was her burden to bear. This book was made into a miniseries back in 2001 and will soon be a movie on Netflix. The latter was given a NC-17 rating so parents of little ones will need to put them to bed before watching. I haven't seen the miniseries but my expectations for the movie are high based on the quality of the source material. Joyce Carol Oates recently said some stuff on Twitter that rubbed me the wrong way, but that won't stop me from praising her talents as a writer. I am not much of a grudge holder, and even if I was, I believe in separating the artist from the art. Blonde is an excellent work of prose. From reading it I feel like I personally knew Marilyn Monroe, which means I feel like I'm one of the many who failed her. That's what excellent historical fiction does, puts readers in that place, in that moment, in those shoes. Now that I'm done with Blonde, I find that what I wish to express has already been stated eloquently by someone else. "Goodbye, Norma Jeane; Though I never knew you at all; You had the grace to hold yourself;While those around you crawled." I recommend Blonde to fans of BIG books. Even if you're an exceptionally fast reader, this isn't a novel that you're likely to polish off in a couple days. I also recommend it to people interested in the golden era of Hollywood. In 2022 anybody can snag a degree of fame by having a popular TikTok channel or something like that, but back in Marilyn Monroe's day fame was reserved for the elite few. The diversity of this group lacked range for sure, but back then there was a clear dividing line between regular folk and mesmerizing STARS. Among them, none were bigger, even with the brevity of her career and lifetime, than Marilyn Monroe....more

title: The Devil in the White City: Murder, Magic, and Madness at the Fair That Changed America
author: Larson, Erik*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'd been curious to read this book for quite some time and finally got around to it. Erik Larson's award winning Bestseller did not disappoint. I am mI'd been curious to read this book for quite some time and finally got around to it. Erik Larson's award winning Bestseller did not disappoint. I am mostly a reader of novels written for the adult market, dominated by works of so-called literary fiction with periodic forays into a variety of genres. But every so often a work of non-fiction will pique my interest. Perhaps a biography of some well known figure, maybe a memoir that has received rave s, or in the case of The Devil in the White City, a book that is not so much an exhaustive examination of a particular individual's life, but rather, a well researched narrative of a particular time period and setting and sequence of events. The time period is the late 1800's, an era known as the Gilded Age due to rapid economic growth, especially in the Northern and Western United States. The place is Chicago, Illinois (though we do venture to other US cities and up into Canada near the book's end). And there are two parallel tracks of events. The first is the conceptualization, construction and realization of the 1893 World's Fair: Columbian Exposition that was held in Chicago. In being chosen to be the site of the Fair, the Windy City was rebounding from the Great Chicago Fire of 1871. The men charged with manufacturing a place of wondrous fantasy were John Welborn Root, Daniel Bunham, Frederick Law Olmstead and Charles B. Atwood. Bunham is basically the main true life character of the World Fair sections of the book, since the buck stops with him when it came to coordinating the many moving parts and pieces that eventually result in The White City. This nickname for the fair was due to the fact that its nearly 200 new buildings of predominantly neoclassical architecture that were intended to be temporary constructions, including the 14 most notable ones, were painted white. I wouldn't categorize myself as a big fan of detailed technical writing about architecture and landscape design. But Larson does a fine job of getting readers to feel the tension as conceptual artists at the top of the chain, hard working men doing the grunt work at the bottom, and everyone in between races to get the world fair ready in time for its planned opening day. Various well known figures from history are name dropped for their contributions to a variety a groundbreaking features and attractions. The brilliant minds behind the Chicago World Fair are in competitive mode as they strive to outdo the previous World Fair that was held in Paris and featured the Eifel Tower as main attraction. Decisions are made promptly on layout of the Chicago version since time is of the essence to have it ready in time for celebration of Christopher Columbus' "discovery" of the new world. But many bids to be the highlight of the Chicago World Fair are rejected for being either unrealistic, insufficiently impressive, or a copycat. Finally winning out is construction not of a bigger, better tower, but an enormous wheel that people can take rides on - the very first Ferris Wheel. Other things making their debut at the Chicago's World Fair were the first performance of the Pledge of Allegiance, Cream of Wheat, Shredded Wheat, Quaker Oats, the brownie, Juicy Fruit gum, Pabst Blue Ribbon beer, a device that made plates for printing books in Braille, a moving walkway, spray paint (which allowed them to paint a bunch of buildings in a hurry), and the first fully electrical kitchen (including an automatic dishwasher). Among those who gave performances at the fair were Harry Houdini and 'Buffalo Bill' Cody. An entire book can and I'm certain has been devoted to the Chicago World Fair, but Erik Larson only gives it 50% of the billing in The Devil in the White City. "The Devil" referred to in the book's title is the serial killer Herman Webster Mudgett, better known as Dr. Henry Howard Holmes or H.H. Holmes. Many of his horrific deeds were done in the shadow of the World's Fair where he owned a hotel. Eventually he was convicted and sentenced to death by hanging for one murder, with no less than 9 deaths confirmed as attributed to him. Holmes confessed to 27 murders and is suspected to have killed as many as 200 people, mostly individuals who came to their bitter ends in the confines of Holmes' so called Murder Castle. Later it was reportedly planned to be turned into a perverse museum of murder, but the building was gutted by a fire that perhaps was arson before this twisted dream could be realized. Some of the people that Holmes' confessed to killing ended up still being alive, so the extent of his murder spree will probably never be known with certainty. Among his various talents and inclinations were bragging and lying for attention, especially once he had nothing left to lose. Not among his victims were the three women that he charmed and was simultaneously married to. Without going into graphic detail, we are shown that Holmes lived up to nicknames given to him such as Dr. Death, The Arch Fiend, and The Torture Doctor. Charles Dickens famously wrote "it was the best of times, it was the worst of times". Larson shows us that the late 1800's in America was a time of great promise and technological progress and also a time of unimaginable horror taking place practically in plain sight. The Devil in the White City alternates between the story of the Fair that put the world on notice of remarkable feats that America was capable of when our brightest and best put their collective minds to it, and the story of a monster in human form who killed at will for his own perverse entertainment, as well as to keep from getting caught. The story of H.H. Holmes no doubt can and has been the focus of a book dedicated exclusively to his evil exploits. After all, he has the distinction of being known as America's First Serial Killer. I watched a short documentary about him after reading The Devil in the White City. Erik Larson interestingly chose to merge two stories into one compelling narrative. I confess to being more absorbed by the creepy serial killer stuff than by the World Fair planning and execution portion. But going back and forth between the tale of American ingenuity and the tale of an American made psycho killer results in a fascinating reading experience. Larson gives us a work of detailed non-fiction that reads like a novel. In the end notes he writes that he chose to recreate just two of Holmes' murders, and in deciding how best to go about it he spent a good deal of time rereading Truman Capote's In Cold Blood for insights. That is certainly a brilliantly written place to go for inspiration. I almost forgot to mention that H.H. Holmes, who by the way was a contemporary of Jack the Ripper but possibly far more prodigious, is not the only murderer to be found in the pages of Larson's book. A mentally disturbed man named Patrick Eugene Prendergast murders the beloved mayor of Chicago, Carter Harrison - turning the closing ceremony of the Chicago World Fair into a funeral procession. Clarence Darrow defended him but was unable to save Prendergast from the gallows. Unlike Predergast who was captured immediately after his crime, Holmes was able to continue murdering for a long stretch of time. He took advantage of the fact that so many people were visiting Chicago for the World Fair, many of them unaccompanied. A fair number of these tourists never returned home because of an unfortunate choice of hotel to stay at. If it was not for his compulsion to swindle people and avoid paying off various financial debts, Holmes probably could have gone on killing people indefinitely. The reason why he is initially arrested and put in jail is because detectives track him down to account for money he has conned people out of. While he sits in prison, law enforcement realizes that it's no mere conman that they have captured, but a remorseless, relentless serial killer. I'm glad that I finally got around to reading The Devil in the White City. I plan to seek out more books, non-fiction as well as novels, that take place during the fascinating Gilded Age....more

title: When No One Is Watching
author: Cole, Alyssa*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Alyssa Cole's WHEN NO ONE IS WATCHING made for a fun, fast read. It's a story of gentrification made even more sinister than it is in real life most oAlyssa Cole's WHEN NO ONE IS WATCHING made for a fun, fast read. It's a story of gentrification made even more sinister than it is in real life most of the time. The back cover copy describes it as "Rear Window meets Get Out" which is certainly an intriguing tag line. Those happen to be two of my favorite movies. The Rear Window part has to do with characters checking each other out from the window of an across the street apartment. This is done most often by Theo who is the main male character. His counterpart is Sydney Green, a Black woman who the White Theo is drawn to. The fact that his live-in girlfriend is horrible and soon to become his ex-girlfriend who intends to evict him is certainly enough to make Theo check out other romantic options. The setting is a neighborhood in contemporary Brooklyn, NY that is too quickly undergoing changes that most of the residents aren't crazy about. The Gifford Place community has been predominantly African American since well before Sydney grew up there, but of late a lot of the Black folks have been moving away (several under mysterious, unsettling circumstances), and in their place has been the arrival of affluent White people such as Theo's one foot out the door girlfriend - a stereotypically uptight and bitchy woman named Kim. Technically Theo is the one with one foot out the door, but Kim's the one doing the pushing. Sydney first encounters Theo and Kim on a walking tour of the neighborhood. She vocally disapproves of what the tour is highlighting and what it is leaving out, the latter being contributions over the years by the majority Black population of the neighborhood. Sydney decides to create a tour of her own to counter it. And unemployed Theo with plenty of time on hand volunteers to be her assistant, never mind the hostility she does not refrain from expressing about gentrifying White people such as Theo. The man is not without charm though, and Sydney is conveniently single just as Theo is in the process of becoming, so a potential love connection is one of the book's features. It is written in alternating first person point of view perspective - so we get a chapter from Sydney's viewpoint followed by one from Theo's and then back to Sydney and so on and so forth. As the story progresses, peculiar circumstances pile up on each other and suspicions rise from mild to full blown conspiracy territory. Why are so many of their neighbors here one day - gone the next? What could cause the bodega visited just the other day to be replaced with no notice by a store that's far less typical of what the neighborhood has been for decades, but perhaps will not be for much longer? Why isn't Syndey's best friend answering her texts? What does the company that's building a hospital in the neighborhood have to do with the various strange things that are taking place? In the book's final chapters a great deal of action occurs, major revelations are made, allegiances and loyalty is tested, and we take a deep dive into the Get Out-esque aspects of the plot. Cole writes in an easy to digest manner that has you reading speedily along to find out how things are going to work out. It's all a bit too over the top to be considered realistic or literary leaning. Instead, When No One is Watching is a solid mystery/thriller with a couple of likable lead characters that are pleasant to spend time with. Judging from the list of previously published Alyssa Cole titles that are promoted on the final page, she spends a lot of time in the Romance genre. I tend to steer clear of full blown Romance novels, but not of books where romance is an aspect of the story. My taste is my taste. If you're into Romance novels my guess is that you'll like Cole's other books because she is a fine writer. And if your preference in reading material leans towards books with social commentary to make and perhaps a disappearance or two to solve along the way, I recommend that you check out When No One is Watching. I'll be watching out for future Alyssa Cole books, though probably not the ones that feature a man and woman looking longingly at one another on the front cover. I can think of no higher compliment to give an author than that I'm watching out and looking forward to what they come up with next....more

title: Black Buck
author: Askaripour, Mateo*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Black Buck by Mateo Askaripour makes for a quirky, largely enjoyable read filled with social commentary on black/white race relations that veers from Black Buck by Mateo Askaripour makes for a quirky, largely enjoyable read filled with social commentary on black/white race relations that veers from light-hearted to sharply critical. The style of prose goes down easily for readers who prefer accessible writing that rarely sends them to a dictionary or thesaurus to confirm what a word means. The plot follows a young Black man who is not living up to the potential that his scholastic accomplishments suggest is possible for him. Darren not only attended prestigious Bronx High School of Science but graduated valedictorian. Yet rather than moving on to higher education at an elite college, he works at a Starbucks on the ground floor of an office building. He is generally satisfied with his life despite his mother's insistence that he is cut out for far more. This is understandable since Darren and his mother live in a spacious home (along with a tenant downstairs) that his mother owns, he is the manager at Starbucks and fond of the staff, he hangs out with his best friend from early childhood on a regular basis, and he has a beautiful, supportive, soul mate girlfriend. So even though Darren can be considered to be an underachiever professionally, it's understandable why he is content with what he has without yearning for much more. But one day for no particular reason he decides to talk a customer into trying a different drink than his usual selection. The man is impressed with Darren's sales pitch, and he happens to be a sales manager at a start up company in the building. Rhett recruits Darren to become one of his sales people. Initial reluctance is eventually overcome and Darren decides to give it a shot. He and two other recruits go through what seems more like a fraternity hazing period than job training, and Darren (who is the only African American) is given the hardest time by a manager named Clyde. Each of the recruits are given nicknames, and from this point on Darren is known to most as Buck. Without going into too much detail and steering clear of spoiler territory, I'll sum up the rest of the plot in broad strokes. Buck becomes alienated from the people in his former life. His best friend Jason switches on a dime to becoming his enemy, he and Soraya break up, and his mother dies. It turns out that she had cancer and was keeping it secret from Darren, but not from their tenant who is like a surrogate grandfather (Darren's father passed away when he was a child). Darren/Buck is so furious that he was kept in the dark about his mother's condition that he throws the elderly man out of his home even though he has no other family to go to. Buck throws himself full bore into his new world. Being a great salesman at a company that is relentlessly thriving is all that matters. His work colleagues become his new family. Then comes the next narrative shift where Buck ends up becoming a mentor to other African Americans who want to better their situations by become super salespeople. It starts out with just one person, then two, and before you know it, along with his regular job he is running a worldwide but also top secret organization that cranks out success stories. The definition of success being getting hired to be a well paid salesperson in spite of not being White. Is A LOT of the plot of Black Buck over the top? Yes. Are complex social issues boiled down to utter simplicity? You betcha. Did my eyes roll over when plot machinations seemed rather implausible, such as a childhood friend becoming an enemy overnight simply because of a change in jobs? Most definitely. If you consider Black Buck to be in the category of parody/satire then you take much of it in with a large grain of salt. But is that what it is? I went to its Amazon page where there is a Q&A with the author. Askaripour is asked - "Did you set out to write it as a satire?". He replies: "The straight up answer is no. In fact, before people started telling me it was satirical, I treated it as an earnest piece of work. I’ve discovered that it’s both earnest and satirical—and I’ve had to learn how to hold both truths". In my opinion, if you read Black Buck strictly as an earnest piece of work then it is only moderately successful. If you decide that the author isn't really taking this plot fully serious (despite the fact that he confessed he was taking it quite seriously) but instead utilizing it to make pointed observations about society, you may hold this book in higher regard. Either way, it's a breezy read with nifty plot twists at the end that you may or may not see coming. I don't consider Black Buck to be strong, masterful writing - but it does make for easy enough reading. It has an initial lightness of tone with social commentary thrown in that grows darker but not overly intense as the story moves along. The characters serve their roles in moving the plot along more than becoming fully fleshed out people on the page. It's certainly a unique story that doesn't remind me much of anything I've read in the past, and originality (like readability) is easier said than done. I didn't love Black Buck but did find plenty in it to like a great deal, and so I do recommend it. As always, happy reading!...more

title: The Count of Monte Cristo
author: Dumas, Alexandre
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A classic that perhaps invented the genre of Revenge books, if that's a genre, and I suppose that it must be considered to be so. This book has been oA classic that perhaps invented the genre of Revenge books, if that's a genre, and I suppose that it must be considered to be so. This book has been on my bucket list for ages. I now get to check it off the list. I was motivated to finally read it after watching the first season of the series Lupin. My library did not have the original Arsène Lupin source book on hand, so instead I borrowed the legendary novel - The Count of Monte Cristo. It has been a minute since I last read a book written 100+ years ago deploying a flowery type of language that nobody writes or speaks in any more. Back in my school days I used to read such books on a regular basis, and so I was used to it. But over the past couple decades I have primarily read books with a more contemporary feel. Even if the settings of some of the books I've read take place quite a ways back, they were not written during the time period that events take place, and so the prose was more accessible than a book published in 1844. After watching Bridgerton and Lupin back to back I was ready to immerse myself in the distant past, and in a story that we all know something about even if we've never read it or even previously seen a screen adaptation. There are approximately 1000 character names to keep track of in this book (perhaps a slight exaggeration), though only about 500 characters since everybody seems to go by at least two different names from early chapters to later ones. This includes the title character who starts out as Edmond Dantès before going through hell and coming out on the other side with a much fancier title and lifestyle. I can't say that I loved The Count of Monte Cristo. Maybe I was unfairly comparing it to more modern novels, not just the language in which people speak that has gotten A LOT more relaxed over the years, but the storytelling arc and pacing and character motivations and plausibility of the narrative. It was a bit too over the top for my liking, like a soap opera on steroids set in the days of yesteryear. The last old classic I read well after my days of assigned readings was probably The Picture of Dorian Gray. As with The Count, I knew going in from its lofty reputation what Dorian's story was generally about without knowing all of the nitty gritty details. Dorian Gray is a much shorter book with far fewer characters to keep track of than The Count of Monte Cristo. In the end I'm glad that I read both of these books. I'm happy to have checked them off of my book bucket list. I am not one of those people who of late have been broadly disparaging books that are part of the literary canon and are referred to as classics. There are plenty of books falling into this category that I greatly enjoyed, and yes, there are also some that I slogged through. Depending on which section I was up to in The Count of Monte Cristo, sometimes I was slogging and other times I was racing through to see what would happen next. It's certainly not uneventful book. Should I take on that other Alexandre Dumas classic - The Three Musketeers? Perhaps someday. We shall see. I'll close out this  with the final words of The Count of Monte Cristo because they are lovely and profound and worth repeating. “Until the day when God will deign to reveal the future to man, all human wisdom is contained in these two words—'Wait and hope.'” I waited quite some time before finally reading this book. I hoped I would enjoy it. Now I'm hoping that the next book I read will knock my socks off and I don't intend to wait long to find out....more

title: Fool Me Once
author: Coben, Harlan*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This was my second Harlan Coben book, the first being Just One Look. I noted in my  of Just One Look that its infectious page turner style of prThis was my second Harlan Coben book, the first being Just One Look. I noted in my  of Just One Look that its infectious page turner style of prose will be mistaken by no one for literary flair. Strictly meat and potatoes. This writing style effectively accomplishes the goal of all mystery books - to make readers extremely curious about who dunnit and why they dunnit. As I have found to be the case with quite a few mysteries, the grande finale portion where all/most gets solved and the culprits are revealed was a bit underwhelming. The explanation section at the end of Just One Look is so choppy and convoluted and hole punched that I stopped caring halfway through it. In other words, I raced to the end only to find myself somewhat dissatisfied by the destination. Nevertheless, I will be sure to give another Harlan Coben book a shot because he is excellent at leaving a trail of crumbs for readers to eagerly devour, and that's what we read mystery novels for - the thrill of the blind chase. Now here I am, having kept my promise to read another Harlan Coben book, ing Fool Me Once. And I can think of little to say about it that I did not already express in my earlier . My feelings about Fool Me Once are nearly identical to how I felt the last time I closed out a Harlan Coben novel, though I will say that the ending of Fool Me Once where everything gets explained was not particularly convoluted. This isn't to say that there are not a great deal of twists and turns along the way. But the summation of how we got from beginning of the mystery to its end was easy enough to follow. I was hooked on the premise of Fool Me Once from the back cover copy. How can it be that Maya sees her husband playing with their daughter on video filmed by a nanny cam when her husband was murdered a couple weeks earlier, prior to acquisition of the nanny cam? I wanted to know and so flew through this book's pages to reach the final ones where all is revealed. Maya is as tough and bad ass a protagonist as they come, a combat veteran who is tortured by demons that she doesn't let get in the way of kicking ass as the need arises. She doesn't even allow being the mother of a young child to soften her rough edges. Such qualities typically are given to male characters, so it's a welcome feminist change of pace for the relentless hero to be a woman. The two Harlan Coben books I've read to date have had significantly different plots and bring us into entirely different worlds. In this one we encounter cops and soldiers and the uber rich and guns for hire and a fancy prep school administrator and a high profile whistle blower determined to reveal unearthed truths and let them steamroll whoever is in the way. But when all is said and done - it was the similarity of reading experiences from one Coben novel to the next that most struck me. Harlan Coben is very good at what he does. It ain't broke so he does not try to fix it, but instead gives readers one edge-of-your-seat suspenseful thriller after another....more

title: A Gentleman in Moscow
author: Towles, Amor*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A Gentleman in Moscow by Amor Towles has been on my radar for some time. As a 2016 publication it's not especially old, but whenever I would go on a bA Gentleman in Moscow by Amor Towles has been on my radar for some time. As a 2016 publication it's not especially old, but whenever I would go on a bookish web site such as Goodreads, it seemed that someone in my stream had recently read it. Plenty of those readers were hyping it up, but from the synopsis it did not appear to be a particularly eventful story, and I also stumbled upon s by people who weren't feeling it. I'm intrigued by books that people either love or loathe, not too many falling in the middle. So I finally got around to borrowing a copy from the library to discover which camp I would fall into. The title provides a healthy portion of plot summary. Amor Towles' book is not about a spy. It isn't about a war hero. It isn't a coming of age story or a love story or a revenge story. It isn't about someone who comes to see the error of his ways or who comes to an epiphany after some transformative event. The book is literally about a guy in Moscow, and even that can be said to be an overly broad description since he doesn't spend time in very many neighborhoods or locations throughout the city of Moscow. What Count Alexander Rostov happens to be is a gentleman in a fancy, old hotel named the Metropol where he spends decades of his life under house arrest. His crime is a poem that was credited to him. Being that this is Russia in 1922, a poem which can be translated as a call to action of the revolt variety is sufficient cause for severe punishment. Being well connected is why he ends up on house arrest rather than executed. Revolution always seem to be a spark away in Russia, a fact that I was reminded of when a flare up took place there during the time that I was reading this book. It looked for a minute like Putin was about to be bounced, but he is a resilient guy, as is the country of Ukraine that refuses to be taken over by Russian forces. I suppose it will be while I'm reading some other book in the future that Putin's reign finally ends one way or another. Revolutions are a pretty big deal to those who are out on the streets, picking sides, waiting to see how it will turn out and what the repercussions of the result will be. But for a man residing in a hotel who rarely sets foot outside of its walls, it's background noise. A Gentleman in Moscow is about quiet observations of the poetry of the human condition set within narrow physical confines. At the beginning of the story, which has a surprisingly large page count for a book about a guy who doesn't go anywhere and do all that much, Rostov is booted from a luxury suite and relocated to a much smaller room in the hotel's attic - his small world rendered even smaller. Uncomplainingly he decides on which possessions will make the trip with him since he won't have room to keep everything. With quiet dignity and aristocratic bearing he goes about the business of living for days, weeks, months, years while the world outside goes on without his participation. He befriends a young girl who is mature beyond her years that is staying with her family in the hotel for an extended period of time. This takes place shortly after Rostov gets his faced shaved clean for the first time in however long it has been, a fact that initiates their first conversation. The friendship proves pivotal for two reasons. The first is that for some reason she has a skeleton key that can any open any locked door in the hotel, and shortly before leaving she gifts this key to Rostov. The second reason is that years later as a married woman with a daughter, Nina returns to the Metropol and leaves Sophia behind with her childhood friend while she goes off in search of her husband who was sent to Siberia. Nina never returns and so Count Rostov finds himself in the unexpected role of father. He also lands himself a girlfriend. Eventually he gets a job, working as a waiter in the hotel. He has a clique of good friends who are also employed there. Rostov ends up with the bulk of things that people aspire to acquiring - a partner, family, friends, an occupation that he is well suited for. He has everything except freedom. The primary missing ingredient in his life is mobility. Prior to his sentencing to house arrest, he was a wealthy, well traveled man who was content with his circumstances, saddened only by the early death of his sister. After his confinement at the Metropol he remains the same person with the same demeanor as the world keeps spinning. But the thing is, while the happenings of the world at large do affect us and sometimes fascinate us, the private lives we each lead are what matters most to us. Whether a Democrat or a Republican is in charge, whether economic indicators are up or down, whether it's a time of war or peace, stability or upheaval, we have our inner circles that remain largely untouched by the maelstrom outside our doors. For a stretch of pages I found myself astounded by how little was happening in this novel in terms of plot development. Yet I happily kept reading because it was such a pleasure to bask in the nothingness, in the microscopic examination of the beautiful minutiae that surrounds us daily. Whatever can be appreciated is a treasure. It might be a fresh shave, or a quality meal, or a melodic tune, or a pleasant conversation. Our ability to appreciate it is what makes a kingdom of our immediate surroundings, whether that kingdom is a humble room, a luxury suite, a stately palace, or the opportunity to reside in a wide variety of locations throughout the globe. We aren't made rich by how much we acquire, but by how much we value whatever it is that we have on hand and in our hearts. In the end, consider me among those who were enchanted by A Gentleman in Moscow. I was reminded of the movie The Terminal. National treasure Tom Hanks stars in that one as a guy who is stuck at an airport terminal for weeks because upheaval in his homeland has made him a man without a country. Due to interactions with the airport regulars, this airport takes on a feeling of home rather than being like an isolation cell in a prison. It's in another movie, Cast Away, where we see Hanks in a true solitary confinement situation, so desperate for companionship that he starts to imagine a volley ball as his friend. Count Rostov is far luckier in spite of acquired misfortunes than a guy stranded on a deserted island, because relationships with our fellow man provide us with infinite currency. This lesson is elegantly displayed in Amor Towles' fine novel....more

title: The Nickel Boys
author: Whitehead, Colson*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The Nickel Boys vaults to the top as my favorite Colson Whitehead book. It is based on the true story of the Dozier School for Boys, a now-closed juveThe Nickel Boys vaults to the top as my favorite Colson Whitehead book. It is based on the true story of the Dozier School for Boys, a now-closed juvenile reform school in the Florida Panhandle, where former students have told stories of beatings and sexual abuse and where investigators have found dozens of unmarked graves. At the start of The Nickel Boys we are introduced to a man who we learn spent a portion of his youth in a reform school that made no attempt at reforming or educating. The Nickel Academy was a brutal place for young white men to wind up, and for young, dispensable black men - it was pure hell. Especially when the black kid is a conscientious, diligent, dutiful son and model student planning to attend college. The last type of person who should end up in a reform school. But when he hitches a ride in the wrong car, one that has been stolen, Elwood is considered to be an accessory to the crime and his promising future is derailed. Memories of Nickel haunt the men who served time there, and buried along with secrets are bones that once held up the bodies of those who failed to walk out at the end of their internment. In the Jim Crow south black people had very few rights in a society that invited cruelties against them. As bad as it is on the outside, black boys in a place like Nickel, most of them lacking in concerned family members waiting at home for them, can be tortured to death and made to vanish without a trace. Those who make it out are mostly broken men. But there are certain individuals who remain free of subjugation even while imprisoned. And once release from bondage is achieved, such men not only survive but thrive. No matter that they are forever scarred, because a place like Nickel always leaves its marks. Whatever doesn't kill you can destroy mind, body and soul in various ways, unless you are the type of person who is strong enough to lift the heaviest of burdens and rise above enslaving circumstances and shape a life worth living when freedom is at hand. The type of person who understands even in the midst of the grittiest of circumstances, the value of shimmering hope. Whitehead's prose is skillfully rendered and makes for easy to digest reading. He paints a bleak landscape with his words in telling a tale drenched in sorrows. This  will remain spoiler free, though I must add that I did not see the brilliant ending coming. It is one that causes you to re-evaluate all that came before it. Similar themes are addressed in the novel Sleepers by Lorenzo Carcaterra and the miniseries When They See Us - directed by Ava DuVernay. So if you enjoyed The Nickel Boys as much as I did and have not yet read Sleepers or seen When They See Us, you may want to do something about that. Another very famous story addressing similar themes that I happen to be currently reading is The Count of Monte Cristo. Similar themes addressed and yet somehow stories that are quite different from each other since the same basic story can be told in many significantly different ways....more

title: The Light in the Ruins
author: Bohjalian, Chris*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The narrative of Chris Bohjalian's The Light in the Ruins jumps back and forth between the years 1943 and 1955. The earlier setting takes place in an The narrative of Chris Bohjalian's The Light in the Ruins jumps back and forth between the years 1943 and 1955. The earlier setting takes place in an Italian countryside during World War II. Mussolini's Italy was an ally to Hitler's Germany during the war, but for a portion of that time German soldiers treated Italy like an occupied nation rather than viewing its citizens as brothers in arms. During this period of uneasy alliance, members of the wealthy Rosati family have complicated relationships with the German military as well as with their less prosperous neighbors. The Rosatis host parties for the Germans (because refusing would have given them dangerous enemies), the two adult sons serve in the military and therefore are in partnership with the Germans, and their beautiful sister falls in love with a German soldier whom she believes to be more decent and humane than his comrades. The Rosati family's cozy relationships with Germans (which is set in motion by the wish of Germany to not only take over the world, but also to plunder much of its art in the process, and the Rosatis happen to have an ancient Etruscan burial site on their land) is a recipe for resentment by those who are distrustful of the Nazis and anyone who chooses to associate with them. Flashing forward to the 1950's the book's plot revolves around a serial killer who for unknown reasons is targeting members of the Rosati family, ripping the heart out of each victim to cap off the vicious murders. Two Italian detectives are on the case, a man and a woman, the latter having a relationship with the Rosati family that dates back to the war when she was severely injured and they helped nurse her back to health. Being a woman police office, an armed one, makes her a rarity in this place and time. As the fast paced novel draws to its conclusion on a dual track we learn the identity and motivation of the killer in its final pages. I neither loved nor hated this book. I suppose that I expected or hoped for a little more from it. The writing is somewhat boilerplate but effective enough to keep readers engaged and curious to see how things will work out. If you're a fan of whodunnits (not that this is one you'll have any chance of figuring out on your own), and of war novels, and of historical fiction with a dash or romance, and of art history - The Light in the Ruins will reward you with all of these elements. You may or may not fall in love with this book. You definitely won't be bored by it. This is the second Chris Bohjalian novel I have read, the first being Trans-Sister Radio. These books cover radically different subject matter so I'll have no idea what to expect from any of his other novels if and when I decide to give him a third chance....more

title: The Water Dancer
author: Coates, Ta-Nehisi
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I enjoyed this well written book, the first novel by esteemed writer Ta-Nehisi Coates. It received a great deal of hype including the valuable OPRAH sI enjoyed this well written book, the first novel by esteemed writer Ta-Nehisi Coates. It received a great deal of hype including the valuable OPRAH seal of approval. So I went in thinking it would blow me away. Instead I ended up liking but not quite loving it. 3-1/2 stars out of 5. Comparisons to The Underground Railroad by Colson Whitehead were inevitable since they both tackle the same subject matter. Both books stray from the reality of what the underground railroad was in the telling of their respective tales. In Whitehead's case he made it a literal train traveling underground, so basically the subway. As for Coates, he came up with the concept of conduction which is where certain people (such as Harriet Tubman who is a character in The Water Dancer) possess the mystical power to transport themselves and others along with them over great distances rather than needing to travel in pedestrian fashion by horse or foot. It's kind of bordering on Harry Potter territory. The Water Dancer delves into the life of a man named Hiram Walker who is a slave in possession of the power of conduction, although for much of the narrative he doesn't have full mastery of it or control over when it will happen. But even though he isn't a conduction expert yet, his talent makes the operators of the Underground Railroad greatly desirous of his services. Unlike Hiram and Harriet "Moses" Tubman, most slave escapes are orchestrated by people without magical powers. These ordinary escapes involve strategy, forgery, and following paths that lead to various locations of shelter by abolitionists when perilous journeys from bondage to safe haven in the northern half of the US are undertaken. Hiram, like many slaves, has half African ancestry and half Caucasian. His biological father is also his master. He is treated better than many other slaves, not quite like a son by his father or like a brother by his father's officially recognized son Maynard. But Hiram is certainly treated better than a brute animal, in part because of his talents beyond conduction such as an incredible memory and mastery of card tricks that entertains guests at parties. In blood as well as circumstances, Hiram has a lifestyle somewhere in between that of "The Tasked and that of "The Quality". But neither he nor those he loves best has freedom, and without that precious commodity, time on this earth is just an advance p of Hell with stolen moments of sweetness all the more cherished because they can be taken away on a whim at any time. I didn't feel as emotionally invested in Hiram and the woman he loves (Sophia) and the woman who raises him after the death of the mother he barely remembers (Thena) as I was in the protagonist of Whitehead's Underground Railroad, or that of the wonderful Freeman by Leonard Pitts Jr.. I wasn't as impressed by the writing as I was by the prose in Edward P. Jones' The Known World or Charles R. Johnson's Middle Passage. I wasn't as absorbed in The Water Dancer as I was by the remarkable Kindred by Octavia E. Butler. Coates has not taken the literary throne from Toni Morrison and her novels such as Beloved and A Mercy. But this isn't to say that I did not enjoy The Water Dancer. It's just that I've read some incredible books that deal with the abomination of slavery. Ta-Nehisi is a very talented writer and I hope he continues gifting us with both his fiction and non-fiction writing on any topic of his choosing....more

title: The Magician's Assistant
author: Patchett, Ann
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I grabbed a copy of this book from the borrowing library at my local train station back in the pre-Covid days when I commuted into work at least once I grabbed a copy of this book from the borrowing library at my local train station back in the pre-Covid days when I commuted into work at least once per week. My wife ended up reading it before me and gave it her highest recommendation. Eventually I got around to it and I share her opinion that this is a wonderfully written novel by Ann Patchett. It is a quiet, slow paced story. Don't grab a copy if you're looking for international intrigue and a lot of car crashes. What you'll instead find within the pages of The Magician's Assistant is plenty of internal exploration by the protagonist to learn who she truly is, which starts out by embarking on a physical and emotional journey to discover who her deceased husband was. Early on we learn that Sabine's husband has just died. We also learn that his lover Phan died of AIDS not long before, which informs us that Sabine was married to a gay man - the magician whom she assisted. I don't consider this to be a spoiler because the reader is given this information in the book's earliest pages. The next revelation, which comes as a total surprise to Sabine, is that her husband was not an orphan bereft of any family other than her and Phan. Shortly after Parsifal's death (not caused by AIDS which he had but had not made him sick yet, but due to a ruptured aneurysm), we learn that his mother and two sisters plus a couple nephews are alive and well. And to them his name was Guy. Parsifal's greatest magic trick it seems was complete reinvention of himself. The first version is a gay boy growing up in Nebraska, dreaming of being anyplace else. The second version is a gay man (with a wife as well as a male lover) who has found that place in Los Angeles, California, performing magic shows for the joy of it and selling antique rugs for great profit. Sabine's willingness to be married to someone who is not physically attracted to women feels like a mystery to the reader - or at least it did to me. The only answer we receive is that she loved him and failed to find anyone else who made her feel the same way. So she accepts what seems to be half of a marriage at best. But when Sabine learns that Parsifal had been lying to her for years about having a family, and then learns that Parsifal's mother and one of his sisters have traveled to LA to meet her, she throws herself into solving the full mystery of her husband's life. There is one more secret in store for her to learn about Parsifal. I won't give that one away. Sabine finds out that Parsifal's family is not full of people who drove him away over intolerance of his sexuality. Her expectation that this must have been the explanation for Parsifal's secrecy and denial of his past is not met, which only deepens curiosity over decisions made by the man she assisted in work and loved offstage. And so Sabine goes back with her newly discovered in-laws to Nebraska where she hopes to unearth the full story of the magician's life. By excavating through his past and getting to intimately know the people who share his blood, Sabine hopes to find a way to move on from torturous mourning. And this assistant who is rather adept at magic tricks in her own right is able to shuffle the cards of loss she has been dealt, and somehow pluck from the void the start of a brand new family and potential for happiness. Ann Patchett pulls us in with skillfully rendered prose that keeps readers hooked throughout the story's twists and turns - weaving a tale that is absorbing from its surprising start to its quietly satisfying conclusion....more
